DATE December 22nd, 1947. Agent

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6403, File 831-5, part 5)
Mr. G. Selvig, Contractor, Prince Rupert, B. C.

This is your authority to proceed with the following work at the Teacherage, Metlakatla Indian Village, B.C.:

1. Reshingle the main roof on the roadside of the house.
2. Put on new flashings on the entire roof where indicated.
3. Put on new ridge boards.
4. Check chimneys and stop present leakage into house.
5. Put Donnaconda Board on walls and ceilings of pantry, living and dining room on ground floor. Use your own judgment as to size of sheets.
6. Repair door and porch on water side of living room.
7. Repair door into basement.

Your invoices covering this work with detail of labor and material to be forwarded to this office.

It is understood that you will be able to make arrangements to take your men over to Metlakatla each day.

The Agency Launch will make a trip with the shingles and Donnaconda Board. When ready to load, please give the office notice of time.

F. Earl Anfield.
Indian Agent.

COPY.
Prince Rupert, B. C.
December 23rd, 1947.

Major D. M. MacKay, Indian Commissioner for B. C., Vancouver.

Attached please find voucher no. 1285 in the sum of $1230.45 being account rendered by Gunnar Selvig, P.O. Box 654, Prince Rupert, B. C. This firm was given the job of repairing the roof and carrying out other approved repairs to the Metlakatla Day School as outlined in the attached copy of instructions to Mr. Selvig in this regard.

Due to very bad weather, the work was delayed until late in the fall when Mr. Selvig rushed a crew over to Metlakatla and put on the new roof and later carried out the interior repairs.

I went over to inspect the completed work at which time the foreman pointed out to me the very dangerous condition of the main timbers supporting this building. The hazard of collapse was such that I instructed the foreman to proceed immediately to open the front of the building up for further inspection, which revealed that all holding timbers had rotted leaving only 1/2 inches of holding space on two of the supporting posts and not more than 3 inches of holding surface on any other posts in the foundation. Further examination disclosed that on the front verandah the upright posts and cross timbers were in an advanced state of rot. On my return to Prince Rupert I contacted Mr. Selvig and instructed him to carry out such repairs as would make the building safe. He was unable to give any price on this type of work but dispatched five men the next day. The final accounts have now been received showing an over expenditure of $575.45 over the sum authorized. Needless to say receipt of this account came as a shock, it being my understanding with Mr. Selvig that the work should not cost more than $200.00. In conversation with Mr. Selvig this week he went over the accounts in detail and advised that had this work not been done, the entire structure would have been grossly unsafe. Once started he had to carry timbers right through the building and reinforce the entire verandah to make the place safe in order to protect the investment already made of a new
roof and the lining with Donnaconda board.

I am not sure if you know this building personally. It has a gigantic roof and the weight of which is carried by the verandah posts on the front side. Repairs to this and the timbers beneath them were essential and whilst I regret exceedingly the tremendous expense incurred on this old building, I could see no other way out than to have the work proceeded with immediately.

Application is, therefore, made for an emergency sum of $575.45 to meet the further costs of repairs on this building. I realize that this should have been placed before the Department for authorization but I had not idea at the time that the damage was so extensive nor that it would be so costly. I am prepared, if necessary, to accept responsibility for this work and if the Department so decide will meet the cost myself from monthly deductions from my salary.

I may say that my only desire was to keep the school at Metlakatla in operation where we have a first class teacher and a grand bunch of children whose attendance is now at an all time high. The physical plant at Metlakatla is a sad story and it seems that I have fallen heir to its collapse both as to the school and the teacherage. May I say personally that I am sorry this additional cost has cropped up and regret having to add this worry to the closing days of your Commissionership in B.C.

F. Earl-Anfield.
Indian Agent.
Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. of Mines and Resources, Ottawa.

Your File 168-3-5 (W.T.1)

Under date of August 13th, 1947, the Department authorized an expenditure of $655 for repairs to the teacher's residence at Metlakatla. Immediately following receipt of your letter the Indian Agent was instructed to proceed to have the work carried out but nothing further was heard from him in regard to the matter until receipt of the attached letter with vouchers covering a total expenditure of $1,243.20.

Mr. Anfield incurred the additional expenditure of $588.20 without any reference whatever to this office despite the fact that there is a daily air mail service between Prince Rupert and this city, as well as telegraphic service always available; consequently I am not impressed with the explanation he offers nor am I at all satisfied that the urgency was such that it precluded reference to this office for authority in the usual way.

Mr. Anfield apparently is a frequent offender in incurring expenditures without the requisite authority despite repeated warnings and the Department may find it necessary to put a stop to this practice by confronting him on some occasion with the necessity of having to meet the unauthorized outlay himself.

The accounts in question are being recommended for payment and if the expenditure is to be a charge against the $47,500 authorized for new schools and additions in British Columbia please advise as it will be necessary to curtail the building program in the Kwawkewlth Agency now underway.

W.S. Arneil
Indian Commissioner for B.C.

AIR MAIL

Mr. W.S. Arneil, Indian Commissioner,
P.O. Box 70, Vancouver, B.C.

We have your letter of the 6th instant, file 12-11-3, enclosing communications from Indian Agent Anfield with reference to voucher 1285 in connection with repairs to the teacher's residence at Metlakatla. After considering the voucher that you forwarded we find it necessary to return it in order that you may adopt the under mentioned procedure.

Please arrange to have two vouchers issued -

(1) Voucher for materials amounting to $389.14, plus the 10% on this amount which is the contractor's fee and should show on the account which makes a total of $423.05. Attached to this voucher should be a new account from Gunnar Selvig showing the items mentioned only and to which should be attached the receipts from the firms from whom the contractor purchased the materials. You can issue a purchase order for this amount and attach it to this voucher.

(2) Another voucher should be issued for the item of boat hire, plus the wages of the five persons engaged in the work, plus the Workman's Compensation Board charge, plus the contractor's fee of 10% which will make a total voucher of $793.60. On this voucher the number of hours each man was employed should be shown, the rate per hour and also the dates on which these men were employed.

Both vouchers, of course, should be certified
by the Agent and also certified by you. When these are forwarded, further consideration will be given to the payment of same.

It is our intention to communicate direct with Mr. Anfield later regarding his action in incurring expenditures without authority. A copy of this communication will be forwarded to you.

Bernard F. Neary
Superintendent of Education.
February 6th, 1948

Metlakatla - your file 168-3-5 (E.1)

I am in receipt of an Army Signals message from Mr. Indian Agent Anfield enquiring as to whether or not vouchers in favour of Gunnar Selvig, Prince Rupert, B.C., prepared in accordance with the instructions contained in Mr. Neary's letter of Feb. 16th, have been received and passed for payment.

Apparently the contracting firm of Gunnar Selvig is urgently in need of the funds.

W. S. Arneil,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.
Ottawa, April 10, 1948.

Mr. W.S. Arneil, Indian Commissioner,
P.O. Box 70, Vancouver, B.C.

With reference to your letter of the 2nd instant, file 12-11-3 (168), regarding payments due Mr. Selvig for work done at the Metlakatla teacher's residence. I understand from the Treasury Branch that at least one of the cheques has gone forward and that the other will be sent this week.

It might be well to point out to Indian Agent Anfield that the delay in paying Mr. Selvig is due in large part to the fact that Mr. Anfield totally exceeded his authority in connection with the cost of the repairs to the Metlakatla teacher's residence. Possibly Mr. Anfield will advise Mr. Selvig to the above effect so that Mr. Selvig will realize that the delay in payment is not due to inaction on the part of head office.

Bernard F. Neary
Superintendent of Education.

MEMORANDUM

Re: Metlakatla Indian Day School,
Skeena Indian Agency, British Columbia.

With reference to your marginal notation dated the 29th ultimo, on a memorandum from Mr. Hoey dated June 28th regarding the above, the sketch plan and specification submitted by the Northwest Construction Company, to the Indian Affairs Branch, do not present a complete and satisfactory picture.

The structure proposed would be very temporary, resting only on concrete pads, having 3" x 3" studs at 2'-0" centres for what appears to be a 13 or 14 foot wall. There is no indication of bridging for the horizontal series of 8 windows and a door, on the south side. One of the most desirable features of "Loctave" construction, the tension joint at corners, is not provided. Wall insulation is not quite sufficient and no insulation is indicated for the floor which is supported by beams above grade.

Electrical data supplied is too vague for analysis. The proposed 3/4" x 160°-0° water service connection is too small.

In view of the fact that material for the building, with very minor exceptions, is to be supplied by the Dominion Government, and that it is prefabricated, requiring reassembling only, the price of $9,850.00 appears to be high, and we do not recommend acceptance.

The sketch plan and specification which accompanied Mr. Hoey's memorandum are attached for return to Indian Affairs.

Enclos.: R.A. Gibson, Esq.,
Director,
Lands and Development Services Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,

TO HIS EXCELLENCY

THE GOVERNOR GENERAL IN COUNCIL.

The undersigned has the honour to report

THAT it is immediately necessary, and funds are provided in the 1948-49 estimates, Indian Affairs Branch, Mines and Resources, to provide a one-room Indian day school with attached teacher's residence on the Metlakatla Indian Reserve, Skeena Indian Agency, in the Province of British Columbia;

THAT it is essential that educational facilities be provided for the Indian children on the Metlakatla Indian Reserve;

THAT Section 36 of the Public Works Act, Chapter 166, R.S.C., 1927, provides in part as follows:

"Whenever any works are to be executed under the direction of any Department of the Government, the Minister having charge of such department shall invite tenders by public advertisement for the execution of such works except in cases (a) of pressing emergency in which delay would be injurious to the public interest......."

THAT, due to the very isolated situation of this reserve, there are no builders or contractors in the area from nor are outside contractors interested in tenders if invited as aforesaid, as they have all the work they can do in their own localities;

THAT a competent building company, namely Prefabricated Structures Limited, Post Office Box 439, Vancouver, British Columbia, has agreed to undertake the provision of a prefabricated school with attached teacher's residence immediately on a basis of $5,850.00 f.o.b. Vancouver, plus freight and erection supervisor's wages, fees and expenses;

THAT it is considered that the provision of this school is a pressing emergency and within the exception provided in Section 36 above recited and further, it is considered that the work can be more expeditiously and economically executed as suggested herein.

The Committee of the Privy Council have had before them a report, dated 13th August, 1928, from the Acting Minister of Mines and Resources, representing:

That, due to the very isolated situation of this reserve, there are no builders or contractors in the area nor are outside contractors interested in tenders if invited as aforesaid, as they have all the work they can do in their own localities;

We have your letter of the 31st ultimo, file 12-11-3, with reference to the Metlakatla teacher's residence.

We have carefully considered the contents of your letter and it is felt that the quotation of $8,259.00 for moving the prefabricated building to the site and providing a foundation, is extremely high.

In other parts of the country a foreman is engaged and Indian labour is used for the construction of the foundation. The work can be done under the general supervision of the Indian Superintendent.

It has always been our understanding that the Metlakatla Indians are an advanced group and we feel it should not be difficult to secure proper Indian labour at Metlakatla. By constructing the foundation in the manner suggested, there should be a considerable saving.

Please give the matter further consideration and let me hear from you again.

Bernard F. Neary
Superintendent of Education.
To make sure that this bid is low I have asked Northwest Construction Company to put in a bid also. This will be wired to you tomorrow afternoon by army signal.

With regard to doing this job on a day labour basis, I have scoured the city for a competent foreman with experience in prefabricated structures. Work in Prince Rupert is very plentiful and competent help is almost impossible to obtain.

The Metlakatla men are still out fishing and will not be through setting until November 15th by which time this building should be just about finished if the contracts are let at once. It is considered that sufficient labour of an efficient type would be impossible to obtain for this job from this village. These men are fishermen, not carpenters and the cost on a day labour basis would be exorbitant. I would quote the experience of the Kitkatla water system as an example of the difficulties that might be expected with Indian labour unless a competent foreman could be supplied by Prefab Structures Ltd.

Whilst I am willing to supervise the work if the Department insists on doing it by day labour with a competent foreman, I would respectfully point out that apart from Miss Batt, I am without competent assistance in the office, in addition to which I will necessarily be away a great deal in October and November in the distant villages.

It is therefore recommended that subject to a lower bid from Northwest Construction Ltd. tomorrow, the contracts be let to Mitchell & Currie and other sub trades as submitted.

Preamble to attached Tender for Metlakatla School and Teacherage

Mr. Jack Martin, our General Superintendent and myself have inspected the proposed site and in order to clarify our tendered price, we beg you to take the following points into consideration and thereby realize the difficulties attached thereto, which we must overcome. Viz -

1 All materials must be handled frequently during transhipment from Prince Rupert dock to actual site.

2 There being no dock at Metlakatla suitable for the landing of materials.

3 Beaching point for scow is in an exposed position and the use of an alternate sheltered point is expected during course of project which will increase cost of handling considerably.

4 There is the possibility of bad weather necessitating the holding of scow at Prince Rupert and thus increased demurrage would be entailed.

5 We have allowed for the employment of a standby vessel to facilitate the protection of the conveyance and its cargo as well as to supply transportation to Prince Rupert for any emergency which might arise.

6 There being no accommodation in suitable condition for housing personnel, an allowance for the cleaning and overhaul of existing building is included.

7 Due to the shortness of suitable working time we have and will guarantee the complete co-operation of all subtrades.

8 Our estimated time for completion of project would be ten weeks from acceptance of contract and delivery of materials shipped by Prefabricated Buildings Ltd., Vancouver.

NORTHWEST CONSTRUCTION LTD.

[Signature]
Neil G. Kingston
Managing Director
We have carefully examined the site of proposed building and have checked our material and labor requirements for the construction of Multi-Flex building specified for this project and beg therefore to submit our tender and recommendations.

The Photostat of plans show a full concrete wall extending to bottom of floor joists, which is, in our opinion, superfluous, considering local conditions. Concrete wall to 6" above earth grade would be adequate in this instance.

We have, however, quoted on both full and half walls and would be pleased to conform to Department requirements in this matter.

We would like to recommend the change of roofing material from Cedar Shingles to asphalt shingles, which we feel are certainly suitable to local conditions. This change would not entail any increase in cost on our part and should be supplied at the same price from source.

"To the erection and completion of building specified, on Photostat submitted by "Prefabricated Structures Ltd., Vancouver" —which would include the following work,

1. Supply transportation for all materials and labor from Dock at Prince Rupert to site at Metlakatla.

2. Supply labor and material for concrete walls and floors in specified building.

3. Supply all labor and material for chimney as per plan.

4. Supply all labor and material for the installation of concrete Septic tank and rockpit required by Provincial health code for twenty persons.

5. All labor and equipment for excavation of basement and walls to adequate soil bearing strata and for the moving and rough grading of spoil.

6. All labor and material required to take care of basement drainage of surface water.

7. Sanding of all finish floors, preparatory for the varnish in Teacherage and oil in School area.

8. Supply and erect partitions in basement of school area for proposed sanitary facilities (Toilets and basins) Three each for boys and girls.

9. To co-ordinate the work of all sub-trades to satisfactory completion of project and to leave building and site in clean and proper condition for delivery and acceptance by the agent for the Department of Indian Affairs.

10. We are not to supply— Any labor or transportation for the sub-trades.

11. The Northwest Construction Ltd to pay all Compensation, Holiday Credits, Unemployment Insurance, Provincial Sales tax on Material supplied by the Northwest Construction Ltd., as required by Dominion and Provincial Statutes.

The Tendered price for the above work would then be $11,635.00 (Eleven Thousand six hundred and Thirty five Dollars)

(This above amount is for all work, including full height concrete wall.)
Should the Department want the wall height lowered to 6" above earth grade there would be a saving of $410.00 (Four Hundred and Ten Dollars) on the above quoted tender price, which in turn would reduce the overall amount to $11,225.00 (Eleven Thousand, two hundred and twenty five dollars).

We request that progress payments be made upon approval of the Department's agent and that upon delivery and acceptance of building that final payment be made within thirty days.

Respectfully submitted for your consideration and approval this 4th day of October 1948.

NORTHWEST CONSTRUCTION LTD.

Certified to be a true copy of a Minute of a Meeting of the Committee of the Privy Council, approved by His Excellency the Governor General on the 17 NOVEMBER 1948

The Committee of the Privy Council have had before them a report dated 5th November, 1948, from the Minister of Mines and Resources, representing:

THAT it is immediately necessary, and funds are provided in the 1948-49 Estimates, Indian Affairs Branch, Mines and Resources, to provide a one-room Indian day school with attached teacher's residence on the Metlakatla Indian Reserve, Skeena Indian Agency, in the Province of British Columbia;

THAT it is essential that educational facilities be provided for the Indian children on the Metlakatla Indian Reserve;

THAT Section 36 of the Public Works Act, Chapter 166, R.S.C., 1927, provides in part as follows: -

"Whenever any works are to be executed under the direction of any Department of the Government, the Minister having charge of such Department shall invite tenders by public advertisement for the execution of such works except in cases (a) of pressing emergency in which delay would be injurious to the public interest ..........."

THAT under the authority of order in council P.C. 3747 of August 25, 1940, a prefabricated school with attached teacher's residence was purchased;

THAT efforts have been made to interest builders and contractors in Prince Rupert in the vicinity of the said Reserve to erect this prefabricated building but they have all the work they can do in their own localities;

THAT two tenders only have been received for the erection of this prefabricated building and that the lower of these tenders has been submitted by Mitchell and Currier Limited, Builders and Contractors of Prince Rupert, British Columbia, in an estimated amount of $7,500.00 which with subcontracts for heating, plumbing, wiring and painting will involve an expenditure of approximately $12,000.00;

THAT it is considered that the provision of this school is a pressing emergency and within the exception provided in section 36 above recited and further, it is considered that the work can be more expeditiously and economically executed as suggested herein.

The Honourable
the Minister of Mines and Resources.
The Committee, therefore, on the recommendation of the Minister of Mines and Resources, advise that authority be granted for the performance of the work on this building as outlined above, this being the only arrangement possible at the present time and it being essential that this work be undertaken at once and carried to completion in order that the building will be available for use by the time the next school term commences.

Clerk of the Privy Council.

Re: Painting of the Metlakatla Indian Day School.

Your 12-11-3 of June 21st to hand. Attached please find amended requisitions for material totalling $359.95. It is not considered necessary to obtain new bids as the unit price on this paint is shown on the bid submitted by Philpott, Evitt & Co. Ltd., this city.

A revision of labour costs has been made and an accountable advance for $500.00 is requested. If it is found that further funds will be required, they will be requisitioned in due course. An additional amount of $100.00 is requested by accountable advance for the labour costs of moving the present school equipment, installing new desks, etc.

Attached please find a bid on painting this school by H. C. McVety, a fully experienced contract painter who has the contract for painting the Cellulose Corporation buildings at Port Edward. He is a first class workman. He was taken to Metlakatla and measured this building up himself. His bid is entirely independent of mine submitted on June 17th. It is noted that his material cost is $684.50 compared to mine of $442.30. His labour cost is about the same. It should be said, however, that he planned to use a painting machine throughout, whereas my bid was for all hand brush work. It should be stated that my bids were based on a two coat job throughout using first class paint which is the only kind that will stand up to the incessant rain fall of this north country.

In line with your request, I have cut this estimate to the minimum and would ask that immediate action be taken to issue purchase orders and forward accountable advances for we will lose what few days of fine weather we may yet have this summer. It would not have been possible to commence painting yet in any case as it has rained incessantly since the contractors turned the building over to us.
In connection with McVety's bid, I should say that he informed me that there would be an additional amount allowed if we were unable to transport this painting machine to Metlakatla on the "Naskeena". This machine weighs about 1600 lbs. and I would not allow it to be loaded on the boat.

F. Earl Anfield,
Indian Superintendent.

Dear Sir:

As I am anxious to have the Metlakatla Indian Day School reopened at the earliest possible moment and there now appears to be every likelihood of obtaining the services of a suitable teacher, I would request that I be given authority to expend a sum not to exceed $100 for the purchase of necessary furniture and equipment for the residence.

Mr. Gillett has supplied me with a list of the articles at present in this residence, some of which are very old, and I note that there is no cookstove included in the list. As there is need for the conservation of any funds available, I am only asking for authority to expend $100 during the present fiscal year, it being essential to provide a suitable cookstove and some necessary furniture.

The Department's decision by air mail is requested.

Re: Agency Building, Teacher's Residence, Metlakatla - (emergency)

In a recent storm the shingles on the side of the roof exposed to the southeast wind were damaged and approximately 1,000 shingles were blown off with the consequences that the house leaked damaging plaster, etc. Upon investigation we found that the nails had rusted. It was unfortunate that galvanized nails were not used when repairs were made in 1936. It appears now that shingles will be continually blowing off. We have made temporary repairs pending further action in this matter.

I recommend that the exposed side be reshingled. The material required is listed on the enclosed form. The approximate cost will be as follows:

TEACHERAGE is a second edition of the School. Old clothes, stockings, underwear, shoes, etc., are scattered in all directions; boxes of empty food cans are piled here and there, and in the kitchen bread, lard, and other edibles are scattered and mouldy. The bathroom is filthy, toilet blocked with excreta. Upstairs, school and janitor supplies are heaped up in some rooms and scattered over the floor in others.

In the attic I found stacks of box files belonging to the Naas Agency as far back as 1895 and a quick scrutiny indicates that these should be boxed up and brought over to the office here until time permits a closer examination and retention of valuable records.

The roof of the teacherage has been shingled on one side only and a fair job done.

I believe that there are sufficient kitchen utensils and supplies to meet the needs of a teacher next year. A new bed and mattress should be bought and apart from this, there is sufficient furniture in the place.

The house must be thoroughly cleaned out from the basement to the roof and the downstairs rooms should be yellowed. Estimate of the work follows:

The teacherage is a large building, designed and built for a very large family. Its upkeep is necessarily expensive. Your 215-8-4021 of May 23rd, 1946, to hand. Mr. Affleck arrived in Prince Rupert on Sunday evening of the 26th, was unable to contact me and left the same night, for Skidegate. He met Mr. Findlay and gave him what amounted to an enlargement of the subject matter of your letter. I wired Miss Merritt offering her Port Edward senior room and received the following reply this morning:

"Not interested in Port Edward Pupils too transient and difficult stop Accept Metlakatla if house and school put in good repair and cleaned Fuel including two tons of coal for house ample supplies dishes and cooking utensils salary as now stop letter in mail - Merritt"

I went to Metlakatla and inspected both the school and the teacherage, which is located in the old Agency building.

SCHOOL is in a most disgusting condition. Text books and supplies are lying all over the room, paper and rubbish on the floor and worst of all, the rats have got in and have eaten the backs and covers from scores of text books. In the spare room, coal is lying around. The school is an absolute disgrace to the Department and it is recommended that $25.00 be authorized as an expenditure for the immediate employment of women to clean the place; to buy rat traps and poison and get the place in some sort of order.

Ottawa.

There would appear to be no alternative however to having the necessary cleaning and repairs carried out and I would recommend that an accountable advance for $150.00 be forwarded to the Agent and that authority be granted for the purchase of a new bed and mattress for the teacherage. Re: Metlakatla School Teacherage.

It will be necessary to make immediate purchase of a kitchen range and a coal heater for the teacherage at Metlakatla. A suitable range can be purchased for $140.00 and a coal burning heater for $72.50 (including freight, delivery and installation at Metlakatla), and authority is requested to make these purchases forthwith.

From the date of Miss Merrett's arrival as teacher of this Day School, she has complained about the kitchen range. I have been over three times myself and checked this equipment and have engaged men to overhaul it and all pipes appertaining thereto, as well as the chimney. It is still unusable except under extremely smokey conditions. The stove is 25 years old and was in the teacherage prior to the advent of Mr. T. A. Bryant as teacher. The ovens are burned through and it is impossible to get any draft. The air vents are broken on both sides of the oven and the bottom flues are rusted through. In addition to this, it has a huge fire box and in order to get any heat at all, the teacher is burning in excess of 100 lbs. of coal per week.

It was my opinion for a while that the teacher was exaggerating the condition of things and following her repeated complaints and a note received last week that unless something was done about it she would have to leave, I spent the whole of Sunday at Metlakatla trying to get this range in working condition but without results.

The Department will save one-half the cost of the new range in reduced fuel consumption. Much as it is regretted to request these payments at this time, I have no recourse but to inform the Department that this stove must be replaced.
at once if the school is to continue this winter. The kitchen ceilings are thick with soot due to the burned-out flues in the stove, and a teacher should not be asked to live under such conditions.

Whilst at this teacherage, I made a careful examination of the furnace, which has not been used for at least five years. It is beyond repair and the heating of this huge house will have to be done by the kitchen range and another coal heater located in the dining room. There is a small coal heater there now but the entire base of it has burned out - in its place there is a sheet of tin which prevents any draft from operating and as a result the stove is useless.

For your information, this teacherage, formerly the Agency, is a huge building, four storeys high, with at least twelve rooms and a basement.

If the teacher is going to be comfortable this winter, a proper heating stove will have to be installed on the ground floor as the furnace is absolutely unusable.

The expenditures are recommended and it is requested that the matter be placed before the Department by airmail.

F. Earl Anfield
Indian Agent.

ARCHIVES PUBLIQUES

CANADA
Prince Rupert, B.C.
February 15th, 1947.

Major D. M. MacKay, Indian Commissioner for B.C., Vancouver.

During the very severe winter weather, the teacherage at Metlakatla developed very serious leaks in the upstairs walls making it impossible for Miss Merritt to continue to live in the bedrooms. There was not sufficient room to place the large bed from upstairs in the dining room, which room was the only dry place in this large house. Miss Merritt was suffering from rheumatism as a result of sleeping in a damp bedroom and rather than have her leave forthwith I procured a small studio couch for her and placed it in the dining room where we have an oil heater which can be kept going 24 hours a day.

The purchase of this studio couch is recommended and vouchers covering same are attached herewith. I have delayed sending these in before as I wished Inspector Davey to see the conditions under which this teacher has had to live.

F. Earl Anfield,
Indian Agent.

Copy for the information of the Dept.
February 25, 1947.

P. L. Anfield, Esq., Indian Agent, Prince Rupert.

I have your letter of February 15th, in connection with the condition of the Metlakatla teacherage, and your Voucher No. 137 referred to therein. The voucher is being forwarded to the Department and recommended for payment, but in future, I would ask that you secure authority from this office before incurring any such expenditures unless, of course, the circumstances are such that immediate supply is an imperative necessity.

With regard to the condition of the teacherage, and in particular the roof, it is noted from our files, that 14 squares of shingles were provided a short time ago, and although it is understood that these were to be used on one side of the roof only, it is not understood why the entire roof was not repaired at that time.

It is noted that an amount of $3800.00 was provided in your 1947-48 estimates for a one-room school with teacher quarters at Metlakatla, which amount appears to be far less than the cost of such a building at this time, unless you had in mind utilizing materials from some other building.

I would appreciate receiving from you, information with respect to the building contemplated at Metlakatla, and the basis on which you arrived at the estimated cost.

D. M. MacKay,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.

We have your letter of the 4th instant enclosing a letter from Indian Superintendent Anfield with reference to the old teacher's building at the Metlakatla School.

As a general rule we have no objection to transferring old buildings for whatever purpose they can be used on a reserve, when they are no longer required for school purposes. April 27th, 1949.

W.B. Arneil, Esq., Indian Commissioner for B.C., Box 76,
Vancouver, B.C.

Re: Old Teacher's residence - Metlakatla, File No. 12-11-3.

Your 12-11-3 of April 21st having reference to the above named subject. The party bidding $3000 on the teacher's residence is Mr. George D. Ryan, presently Chief Councillor at Metlakatla. Mr. Ryan operates a general store at Metlakatla and his wife is Post-mistress. If the building were sold to them they would move the store into the old office annex of the teacherage. The Post Office is already located in a room connected to the office annex of the teacherage.

The teacherage proper is 54 feet long and 40 feet wide and consists of a basement, ground floor, first floor and attic. The attic contains two rooms, closets and shelves. The first floor contains four bedrooms, two large and two small, all plastered. A lot of this plaster is broken away on the north side of the building due to leakage through the walls. Stairways and hallways are in good condition. On the ground floor there is a kitchen, dining room, sitting room, pantry and bathroom. Plumbing is poor. The dining room living room, kitchen and pantry are all lined and ceilinged with donnecona board and are in good shape. The living room has a firelace. The kitchen is equipped with a range, hot water tank and sink. The basement is full with a half cement floor. There is an old furnace, unused and unusable. Foundations are only fair, though as a result of work done a year ago last November, sufficient new posts and timbers are in place to make it safe.

Outside: The roof is in first class condition having been completely reshingled in the past four years. The outside walls are weather beaten and porous due to lack of paint.

General: There is no doubt that this building in any city would be worth a great deal of money. Even in Metlakatla it is a question whether it is worth more than $3000 offered. I believe, however, that the Department would be wise if it is purchased rather than let out privately to one party.

(sgd) F. Earl Enfield
Indian Affairs Branch,
Dept. of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sir;

I have the honour to forward herewith my report on the Metlakatla Indian Day School, Nass Agency. This school was inspected on the 30th of September.

In forwarding this report, I particularly wish to draw your attention to my remarks and recommendations with regard to the establishment of a Manual Training class in this school.

I am very anxious that some sort of Vocational Training be established, where possible, for the boys and girls in our Indian Day Schools. Many of the Residential Schools are now unable to accept any more pupils. In fact, during my last itinerary in the northern part of B.C. I found a number of pupils attending the Day Schools, who last year were pupils of Residential Schools. If it is the policy of the Department to have these children attend the local Indian Day Schools, in preference to more distant Residential Schools, the subject of Vocational Training is of even greater importance in the Day Schools, than it has been in the past.

Your obedient servant,

Gerald H. Barry.
District Inspector of Indian Schools, B.C.

Vocational Training:

Some Manual Training has been done out of school hours by the teacher and boys. Some of this is good. I beg to recommend that the second room mentioned above be turned into a Manual Training shop, by the provision of a heater and terra cotta pipe chimney. An extension of the electric light wire would be required. If the Department would provide two sets of tools (individual) and one set (general), two benches, and the necessary lumber, the teacher would teach this subject. The general set of tools would cost about $120 and the individual sets $10 each, the heater, pipe and wire would cost about $60, making a total of about $200.00. Manual Training would, of course, be taught out of the ordinary school hours.
Ottawa, November 20, 1931.

Sir:

Mr. Barry, Inspector of Indian Schools for the Province of British Columbia, in forwarding his report on his inspection at the end of September last, of the Metlakatla Indian Day School, strongly recommends the establishment of a manual training class. He states that some manual training has been done out of school hours by the teacher and boys and that, if the Department will provide two sets of tools, individual, and one set, general, two benches and the necessary lumber, the teacher will teach this subject. He also states that the cost of the set will be about $120 and the individual sets about $10 each. He further recommends that a room for the purpose be fitted up as a manual training shop by the provision of a heater and terra cotta pipe chimney, at a cost of about $60, making a total expenditure of about $200 in supplying the equipment and fitting up the room. The manual training work would be taught by the teacher after the regular school hours.

I have to request that you will arrange for the purchase from sources which have been indicated to you, of the above equipment and to have a room fitted up for the purpose. The Inspector states that there is an extra classroom in the school building which could be used for the purpose, and that it would be necessary to extend the electric light wire to provide light for this room. Please give this matter your early attention and have the material supplied and the room fitted up in order that this work can be commenced by the teacher at an early date.

Sir:

I beg to forward the enclosed vouchers—Nos.5179 to 5183 inclusive attached to which are accounts amounting to $222.80 for the purchase of a stove, tools, transportation charges and other expenses connected with the equipping of the manual training classroom in the Metlakatla Indian Day School, also abstract of tender form.

As will be seen from the enclosed accounts Inspector Barry's estimate was insufficient to cover the cost of the tools required, besides which the freight charges and the erection of a new chimney had to be met. This accounts for the authorized figure of $200.00 being slightly exceeded.

It will be necessary to have two cupboards made for the safe-keeping of the tools. This work can be done by the pupils, but so far no grant has been made for material for the class to work on. I am enclosing a list of lumber, hardware etc., which will be required for this purpose and shall be glad to receive authority to purchase same.

The class started work in October under the direction of Mr. T.A. Bryant, schoolteacher. Working drawings for the benches were prepared and lumber cut and dressed for the purpose. The pupils are taking a great interest in the work and the training should be of benefit to them.

I would recommend that Mr. Bryant receive $10.00 per month during the time the classes are
open, as the work occupies much of his time after school hours, and I am sure there are very few men who would be willing to devote so much time and energy to the welfare of the Indians as Mr. Bryant does for the people of Metlakatla.

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent.

The Assistant Deputy and Secretary,

EXTRACT FROM REPORT OF INSPECTOR G. H. BARRY,
INSPECTOR OF INDIAN SCHOOLS, following his inspection
of the LETLAKATLA Indian Day School, on May 28, 1933.

Original on 168-3-6.

Manual Training: There are five boys taking this course after school for about five months of the year. During the summer this class does not meet, as the big boys are away. Two small sets of tools and one set for the instructor have been supplied since my last inspection. Two large benches and tool cupboards are now completed. The class is starting on individual projects, and are making drawings to scale. The work done so far is "Excellent". I should like to see such vocational training started in a number of our more efficient day schools. In this case I have been asked to recommend a small grant of $100.00 per annum to the instructor, who is very interested in this work. Owing to the need of money in other directions, I would recommend that Mr. Bryant be paid ten dollars PER MONTH less 10% for the actual months during which Manual Training is carried on at this school, about five a year.

Sir,

I beg to acknowledge the receipt of your l-C-7942 of the 29th ultimo, enclosing voucher in favour of Mr. T. A. Bryant covering remuneration for conducting manual training classes at the Metlakatla Indian Day School during the December quarter. In this connection, I would point out that official letter of September 13th, 1935, only authorized a payment to Mr. Bryant for five months during the academic year 1933-34 and we did not receive any communication from you requesting an allowance for this purpose during the academic year 1934-35.

Mr. Bryant's salary rate as teacher of the Metlakatla Indian Day School is $1,050 a year. If he was allowed $50 for his services in conducting the manual training classes, it would make his total compensation for the year $1,100. The Salary Deduction Act passed at the last session of Parliament provided that, from April 1st, 1934, payment to any official could only be made at the rate of $1,000 a year if his total compensation is between $1,000 and $1,111. Mr. Bryant has been paid $100 a teaching month or at the rate of $1,000 a year since April 1st, last, and, consequently, this is the only amount which we can pay him.

Dear Sir:

I desire to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the third instant and to thank you very heartily for the information contained therein. I may state that a number of requests have reached the Department in recent months from Indian day school teachers in British Columbia, for supplies of material suitable for the promotion of manual training at their schools.

In my reply I have intimated to the teachers that they should communicate with the Indian agent in each case, either personally or by letter, and have him forward their requests with his recommendations to the Department. I feel that we should have the advice and close cooperation of our agents in the promotion of this work. A great many of the smaller schools are not suitable for vocational instruction except in a very limited sense.

This opinion is, I feel, in conformity with the views expressed in your letter.

Yours truly,

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

W. B. Collison, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Prince Rupert, B. C.
Sir:

With regard to the recommendations made by Inspector Barry that native basketry and domestic science should be taught in some of the day schools in this agency, particularly with regard to Gwinsha, Metlakatla and Gitlakdamix schools, and your request that I should give an opinion on same, I would state that where the teacher is capable and willing to carry on a domestic science class for sewing, knitting etc. it should be encouraged.

In some of the day schools in the agency instruction along these lines is already being given. Many of the teachers however, have had no training or liking for these subjects and would naturally not care to take them up. Also where male teachers are in charge of schools it would be a waste of money to employ Indian women as teachers. The Indians now are past the stage when they are satisfied with second grade tuition and unless these subjects can be taught well, no interest will be taken in them and it will merely be an unwarranted expense.

With regard to the question of instruction in native basketry, mats etc. it must not be forgotten that many of the Indians, particularly the younger generation, in their desire to imitate white people and their ways—rightly or wrongly—consider that they have outgrown instruction in such arts as were carried on in past generations of their people.

Whilst this idea is of course ridiculous, the fact remains and unless it is made attractive to the children, classes of this kind will be of no lasting value. Whilst such instruction is successfully given in residential schools where the pupils are obliged to attend classes, the case with day schools is somewhat different.
and unless the children take kindly to it, it will not be successful. This is my candid opinion but I consider where proper instruction can be given an experiment should be made and I would recommend that the Department make available, a sum of not less than $50.00 for each school for instruction in native arts, to be used at the discretion of the agent in any school where such work can be tested as it will be impossible to lay down a hard and fast rule owing to the fact that conditions vary at the different schools.

With regard to domestic science classes, where these are held I would suggest that the teacher be required to send in proper requisitions to the department for the needed material, and where pupils are more advanced a sewing machine will be necessary.

I have not dwelt on the subject of manual training for boys. With the exception of Mr. T.A. Bryant of the Metlakatla Day School; Mr. John Hayhurst, assistant at the Greenville school is the only man fitted to conduct such a class. At the latter school however, there is no accommodation, there being only one classroom.

Naturally the whole question of giving extra tuition in day schools along the lines mentioned is very involved, each school differing from another. We have no facilities as provided in the residential schools where firstclass training can be imparted and materials easily obtained.

Yours faithfully,

Dear Sir:

In reporting regarding his inspection of the Metlakatla Day School on May 7th, Inspector Barry writes:

"I am also anxious to see some Arts and Crafts work started in this school. Baskets could be made with some success if there was an Indian woman engaged for one afternoon a week who knew how to teach such work.

"I understand that Mrs. Alfred Auckland, who is a woman of over 50 years of age, could teach basket making and such other native work as might be necessary at this time.

"It is important that some form of Handwork of use to the Indians be taught in the Day Schools, and I would recommend that a sum of not more than one hundred dollars be authorized as payment for the above mentioned teaching at the rate of five dollars per month. Some material will be very necessary if this type of work is to be carried out in the school. I should like to see some sewing done also, and the children (Girls) should be taught to knit and crochet, while the Boys are working at Manual Training."

I would appreciate having your views on Mr. Barry's suggestion, and, if you approve, you should state definitely how you consider the work could be best handled.

Dear Sir:

I respectfully acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 14th, inst No. 448-2. And in reply may state in regard to the non attendance of children at school Nanaimo reservation, and Mr. Inspector's Green recommendation that I be given authority to round up children of school age and cause their attendance, is most surprising to me to say the least.

I am constantly when in vicinity of schools giving every attention to the attendance of pupils, which can be seen by my diary from time to time, since my appointment as Dom. Constable.

I may say that I have found the question of school attendance a very hard and difficult task, and there is no additional authority that Mr. Inspector Green can have conferred upon me that would bring about any perceptible result for the better.

I have given a lot of attention to this matter in the face of my many other duties, when I visited the school on reservation 13th, inst., I found only two pupils in attendance which I reported accordingly in my Diary stating the almost impossible task of controlling those children at this and other particular seasons of the year, understanding their nature and general circumstances of their parents here and there fishing, digging, clams, catching crabs, others at home minding the house and younger children while the mothers are engaged.
engaged washing scrubbing &c etc for people about the city, all of which and much more has to be contended with, and to be too rash in the governing of the same would in my opinion have a great tendency to do more harm than good.

I informed the teacher Rev. W. J. Knott the other day that I would endeavor if possible and circumstances permitting me, give very close attention to conduct of the parents in causing more regular attendance of their children at school on returning again after the coming holidays which is now only a few days off.

Having the honor Sir,

To remain Yours. Obediently

Report of Inspector Ditchburn for the Month of January, 1912.

Southwestern Inspectorate, B.C.

Herewith I submit my report of inspections made during the month of January, 1912:

The Nanaimo Day School was visited on the 25th, but I only found two children in attendance. This is generally the best day school in this Agency, and the Rev. W. J. Knott is a good teacher and takes a great interest in his work. The trouble here is that the parents will not make their children attend the school. There are over twenty children of school age on this reserve who should attend the school fairly regularly, and Section 7 of the Regulations Relating to Indian Education should be put in force. There would be no use in telling the parents that the children will be put in a boarding school, for until more schools of this kind are provided, there would be no room for them, every boarding or Industrial school being at present filled to its capacity. As Constable O'Connell visits this reserve very often, he should also be empowered to act as Truant Officer. I think if a few of the parents were prosecuted it would have a good effect. I went all over the reserve and saw the parents of absentee pupils, and informed them that unless they saw that their children went to school regularly that they would be fined. I have since been informed that there was a very good attendance the next day.

Sgd. W. E. Ditchburn,
Inspector.
Sir:

Having regard to your letters of the 9th, November last and of the 27th, ultimo, No. II7008/I in reference to attendance of pupils at the Nanaimo Indian day school. I have the honor to report as follows; On receipt of letter dated the 9th, of last November I at once advised the parents of the contents of your letter, and I visited the Nanaimo Reserve on the 25th and 26th, ultimo, in company with Mr. Inspector Bitchburn, there were only two pupils in attendance at the school, we called on all the parents at home, and told them if they did not send their children to school the regulations of the Department would be enforced, the next day there were seven pupils at school. I may say that when the parents are home, they generally send the children off to school and a few of them play truant and go into the City to play with white children who are not forced to attend school. The chief cause for the non attendance is the parents leave the reserve to dig clams and fish when they are absent for about a week at a time and have to take the children with them.

The parents of the children at Nanaimo River did not move to the town reserve this winter as they were employed at

My dear Sir:

Dear Sir:

Yours of August 21st is to hand. You report information from the Chief Inspector of Indian Agencies to the effect that "the bonus paid to Rev. Mr. Kelly as teacher of the Nanaimo Indian day school was deducted by the church authorities from the amount of his salary." Permit me to say that your information is entirely incorrect. The books of the Missionary Society show $600 received from Ottawa on account of the Nanaimo school. The same amount was paid Rev. Mr. Kelly on that account. The bonus, as your Department knows, was not paid through this office, and I did not even know the amount until receipt of your letter today.

The same reply must be made to the latter portion of your letter, where inquiry is made regarding other amounts withheld from salary of teachers on account of the bonus granted; in no case was the bonus paid through our office; and in every case the full amount received on account of salary was paid. Where less than the full annual amount was received, because of shortage in the number of days on which the school was open, the discrepancy was made up by the Missionary Society. A total of $600 was voted to meet these items, which are anticipated and regularly provided for in the appropriations of the Missionary Society.

Of course, Mr. Kelly's salary as teacher is only a part of his income from the Missionary Society. In addition to an allowance for his pastoral work at Nanaimo, he received certain amounts during the year for supervision of the mission work at Cape Mudge. I am having all these accounts investigated in order to ascertain whether any confusion or error in respect of Mr. Kelly's distinctively missionary relations to the Society may have given rise to the mistaken impression conveyed by your letter.

Meanwhile, I should greatly have appreciated an enquiry on the part of the Department as to the handling of
salary and bonus granted to Mr. Kelly and other teachers before the receipt of such a conclusive letter as yours of yesterday.

Dear Mr. Scott:

I beg to acknowledge your further letter in reference to salary of Peter Kelly, missionary-teacher at Nanaimo, and also the enclosed copy of the letter on the same matter from your chief inspector of Indian Agencies.

Having gone carefully into this whole matter I am glad to be able to assure you that instead of having his salary reduced, Mr. Kelly received from the Missionary Society $50 more for the same work than during the previous year, entirely exclusive of the regular government grant and war bonus previously referred to. Examination of our books shows that other missionary-teachers in British Columbia in no case received less out of missionary funds than during the previous year. With only one or two exceptions increases were granted, ranging up to $150.

In further reference to Mr. Kelly's case, it would appear that his complaint to your inspector arose out of a misunderstanding between him and the Missionary Society regarding his remuneration for work which has no direct relationship to the Indian Department. As mentioned in my former letter to you, Mr. Kelly was placed during the past year in direct charge of pastoral work at Nanaimo and in addition had supervision of the mission at Wape Mudge, where no man had been stationed for the year. In the administration of a new scale of salaries adopted by the General Conference of the Methodist Church in October last, there appears to have been some clerical error or confusion by reason of which Mr. Kelly received less than the amount to which he believed himself to be entitled as an ordained minister of the Methodist Church. I am now going into this matter both at our office and by correspondence with the chairman of Nanaimo District and anticipate no difficulty in reaching a satisfactory adjustment when

Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 19th instant, forwarding claim of Miss Jessup, teacher of the Nanaimo Indian Day School, for bonus claimed to be due her for the past year.

In reply I beg to say that, as you were informed by official letter of November 12, 1920, Miss Jessup was allowed bonus at the rate of $150.00 per annum.

During the fiscal year 1920-21, which began on April 1, 1920 and ended March 31, 1921, bonus to Indian school teachers was paid at the rate of $12.50 per month. Miss Jessup was, therefore, paid $12.50 for the month of September; $37.50 for the December quarter and $37.50 for the March quarter.

During the fiscal year 1921-22, which began April 1, 1921, bonus to Indian school teachers is being paid at the rate of $15.00 for each teaching month. She was, therefore, allowed $45.00 bonus for the June quarter and she will be allowed $45.00 for the month of September this year. For the December and March quarters next, if she continues in this school, she will be allowed $45.00 bonus for each of these quarters.

The Indian Day School Regulations referring to the payment of broken periods, do not apply to payment of bonus. There is, therefore, no further balance due Miss Jessup.

Extract from Inspector Barry's Report on his visit to the NANAIMO INDIAN DAY SCHOOL on March 19th, 1936. - Original on File 152-11-6.

Remarks relative to methods employed by teachers:

Miss Klippert was trained in the Toronto Normal School, and holds an Ontario Second Class Certificate. She has attended four Provincial Summer Schools in Victoria, and has as a result received certificates in Primary Work, Leather Work, Pottery, etc.

She taught for some six years in Ontario, and for some twenty-five years in British Columbia. She has been here for a large number of years.

The teacher is making every effort to put into practice some of the methods shown to her when I inspected her school. Miss Klippert is not as young as many of our teachers and for that reason is not able to get through as much work in the day as younger and more modern teachers could do. She is however working hard to get the children on in their work. While I am satisfied that the children are making progress, I wish the Department to know that Miss Klippert is probably in the last five years of her teaching career, as she is not modern enough in methods to be retained after the age of 60 years.

I have taught several lessons for her during the present inspection. These were aimed to interest in particular her older pupils in their work. It is of course just here with the Grade 6, 7 and 8 children that she appears at her worst as a teacher, for they need more time and definite teaching than she can give to them, the greater part of a large attendance being in the Primary and Junior Grades.

Extract from Inspector Barry's Letter, dated March 19, 1936, addressed to Assistant Commissioner Perry, enclosing above report. - Original on File 152-11-6.

I have the honour to forward herewith my report on the Nanaimo Indian Day School, Cowichan Agency, which I inspected today, March 19th, while passing through Nanaimo on my way to Port Alberni.

Mr. Indian Agent Graham was not of course present at this inspection.

There is nothing of a confidential nature to report with regard to this school. The general standing is not quite as good as it was some three months ago mainly because the teacher, Miss Klippert, spends too much time with the Primary Grade and not enough with the Senior Grades. As there are a large number in the school and Miss Klippert is not as young as she used to be, I do not know of any way to remedy conditions at the present time. I do not believe that Miss Klippert should be permitted to teach here after she reaches the age of sixty years. I have reported her present age as 56 in accordance with information she gave me some years ago.

Though I am not asking that any change should be made here at the present time, I have every reason to think that a much younger and well trained teacher, with three or four years experience, would be able to make a very great improvement in the standing of the Intermediates and Senior Grades. I would just ask the Department to keep Miss Klippert's age in view when discussing the work at this school with officials of the United Church of Canada.

Madam:

The Department is in receipt of your letter of the 25th ultimo, enquiring if teachers of Indian day schools are entitled to superannuation.

Teachers of Indian day schools are not classed as permanent Civil Servants. They do not contribute to the superannuation fund as other Civil Servants do and, as a result, no provision has been made to allow superannuation to teachers of Indian day schools on their retirement. The only payment that this Department can allow is a gratuity equal to two months' salary, which, in your case, would amount to $230.00.

I desire to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 22nd ultimo and to state, by way of comment, that there is little I can add to the statement contained in my letter of June 5th.

There is no provision in the Dominion Government Superannuation Act for the inclusion of teachers of Indian day or residential schools. The Government has always considered the obstacles standing in the way of their inclusion insurmountable. In view of this fact, the suggestion contained in the last paragraph of your letter cannot be considered. It has occurred to me that you might communicate with the Annuities Branch, Department of Labour, Ottawa, asking them for a schedule of rates. This is a personal suggestion and one to which you might give consideration.

Yours very truly,

Dear Mrs. Henry,

Having received your letter of the 6th ultimo, re superannuation of teachers of Indian day schools, I am aware that many of the teachers of Indian schools are not fully qualified, while those who are seldom stay with it more than a year or two.

When I entered the work, my chief aim was to give my life to the study of the native peoples especially the training of the children for Canadian citizenship.

Finding on retirement I do not come under the Provincial Pension Scheme, I naturally thought the Department would make some provision for those teachers who might be classed as permanent Civil Servants.

I was wondering if the Department under these conditions, would accept a contribution to the superannuation fund for past service, and what percentage it would be.

Dear Sir:

I have your letter of the 26th instant, with reference to the salary of Miss L. Uphill, teacher of the Nanaimo Indian Day School. I have noted the contents of Mr. Moore's letter.

REPORT ON COWICHAN INDIAN AGENCY FOR THE MONTH OF JUNE, 1943.

Nanaimo, Songhees and Saanich Indian Day schools closed at the end of the month for the summer vacation. The other three day schools in the Agency closed the previous month. I beg to submit herewith a letter-and copy of same-received from Miss L. Uphill, Teacher of the Nanaimo Indian Day School, which I trust you will find self explanatory.

In this connection I wish to say that Miss Uphill has proved herself, in my opinion at least, to be a splendid Teacher with excellent control during school hours both in and out of classroom. She has given a great deal of her own time to the organisation of women's clubs on the reserve not to mention her attendance at same. She has also been a splendid worker for the children of the reserve and the Church in arranging entertainments and concerts-in which the children have taken part-as well as the ordinary school entertainments.

I believe that we are extremely fortunate in having a girl like Miss Uphill in one of our schools. The example she has set the children in cleanliness and her help in encouraging neatness of appearance among the pupils in and out of school has had a splendid effect and the fruits of this teaching can be seen in evidence around the reserve.

I have no hesitancy in recommending that Miss Uphill be put on the same Salary basis as her predecessor who got $10.00 monthly more than Miss Uphill is getting.

W.S. Arneil, Esq. Indian Commissioner for B.C. Vancouver, B.C.

Re: Nanaimo Indian Day School.

I wish to acknowledge receipt of your letter of above date and file and have noted the contents. I read Mr Inspector Davey's report of the 16th ultimo at the time it was received at this Office and immediately felt that the main reason for poor attendance at this school could be put down to the fact that all the pupils had not returned to the reserve at the time Mr Davey made his inspection.

I visited this school last Friday and checked the attendance, which was quite satisfactory. I spoke to Mrs Hill about it mentioning the comments of Mr Davey. She told me that she and Mrs Logie had adopted a new system now, which is an immediate visit to the home of any absentee pupil to find out just what the cause is and that it was working out very well indeed. I signed the register and from glancing casually at the attendance marks on it I got the impression that the attendance was quite good. I did notice that one or two pupils from the River Reserves, No. 3 particularly, were rather irregular but I am reasonably sure that sickness was the reason in those instances. It is impossible for the teachers to check on them as the reserves are 6 miles or so away from the school, however, I did suggest to Mrs Hill that it might be advisable for her or Mrs Logie to take the odd trip out on the bus which takes the pupils home, so that they could find out definitely if sickness was the cause of absence, and I am sure she will do so if necessary. My candid opinion is that most of our teachers do not visit the homes of the pupils half enough, in fact some don't do any visiting, and it shows on the registers.

R.H. Moore,
Superintendent.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6404, File 832-3, part 1)
The Secretary
Dept. of Indian Affairs
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sir:

Owing to the fact that I am not receiving the bonus for this year I consider that my salary is not enough for the amount of work I am doing in comparison with the salaries of teachers in graded schools.
During all the years I taught in the Indian Schools, I have never asked for an increase in salary but now that I have all the grades from the Receiving Class up to Grade 12, which means I have to work overtime in order to cover the work. I feel the salary is not enough, therefore would appreciate very much having the salary I had last year including bonus.

I trust you will give this your favorable consideration.

Respectfully yours,
Evelyn S. Skipworth
Ottawa, September 9, 1925.

MADAM,

In reply to your letter of the 1st instant, I beg to say that, owing to the discontinuance of the bonus from March 31st, last, the Department has increased the salaries of teachers in Indian Day Schools by $150.00 for the academic year. This increase dates from April 1, 1925.

Previously to last April you were paid salary at the rate of $1000.00 a year, plus bonus of $150.00, or a total of $1150.00. As you are aware, your salary was forwarded to you through the treasurer of the Methodist Missionary Society, while your bonus was paid direct to you. From April 1st, last, your salary was at the rate of $1150.00 and for the June quarter a cheque for $345.00 was sent to the treasurer of the Methodist Missionary Society. You will, no doubt, receive this amount for that quarter and you will note that you are now being paid at the same rate as when you were allowed bonus.

Your obedient servant,

Russell T. Ferrier,
Supt. of Indian Education.

Miss E. S. Klippert,
204 Nicol Street,
Nanaimo, B.C.
214, Nicol St.
Nanaimo, B.C.
Sept. 23, 1875

M. M. Turner
Dept. of Indian Education
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sir,

Thank you very much for the information regarding the increase in the salaries of teachers in Indian Day Schools, dating from April 1, 1875.

I have just received the sum of $250 for the June quarter.

Rev. Mr. Macdonald, Nanaimo, is now the missionary treasurer. I will mention the fact to him, as he probably has the balance of the $250 on hand.

Respectfully yours,

The number of pupils here and the interest manifested by the parents would seem to justify the expenditure necessary to erect a new building.

Perrier, Superintendent of Methodist Indian Schools, who were here recently, brought before the Department the need for a new school at Nanaimo. They point out that the present school building is inadequate for the educational needs of the children on the reserve and urge that a new school building be erected during the coming summer on a new site near the church. The Department is disposed to grant their request.

The Indians of the Nanaimo Band have to their credit at Capital Account in the Trust Funds over $67,000.00 and, as a new school building would be for the benefit of all the Indians and represent a permanent improvement, it is considered that the cost of erecting the same should be provided from the above funds at the credit of the band. If a new school building is erected it would be required to provide accommodation for about 40 pupils, and as it will be near the town of Nanaimo, a modern and thoroughly equipped building should be provided. Such a building would cost approximately $5,000.00.

The Department would like you to place this matter before the band in council as soon as possible, representing to them the need of a new building and the value it would be to their children and also that it would benefit the whole band and endeavour to have them pass a resolution setting aside from the funds at their credit the above sum to erect a new building.

MEMORANDUM,

Mr. Scott,

Rev. P. R. Kelly and Rev. T. Ferrier, who were in the office on the 18th instant, drew attention to the need of a new day school on the Nanaimo Indian Reserve. Mr. Kelly is the teacher of this school.

The present building is inadequate for the needs of this reserve. It is old, dark and gloomy and at times is very much overcrowded. Mr. Inspector Cairns has also drawn the attention of the Department to the need of a new building. He said, in his last report of inspection, that a new school building should be erected during 1920, with modern equipment, and that a good school on this reserve, doing first class work, would be a great help in raising the status of other day schools in the province. The reserve is adjacent to the town of Nanaimo, and both Messrs. Ferrier and Kelly pointed out the credit that would accrue to the Department in the erection of a thoroughly equipped and modern school building so near to the town.

During the December quarter there were 37 pupils enrolled, with an average attendance of 27. On some days 36 children attended, although it was hardly possible to accommodate them for lack of space and seating arrangements.

Messrs. Ferrier and Kelly recommended that a school be built to accommodate 40 children, as there are that number on the reserve, about 35 of whom live near the school, and there are 10 other children who reside on the Nanaimo River about five miles distant.

The Nanaimo Band have $67,467.90 to the credit of capital. This amount is made up from royalties received from coal mined on the reserve by the Canada Western Fuel Company.

A sum.
A sum sufficient to erect a suitable building for 40 children and equip it thoroughly could be taken from the above amount under Section 89, Sub-section 2 of the Indian Act.

I would recommend that steps be taken to have a new building erected during the coming summer, and that Mr. Agent Robertson be instructed to call the band together and lay the matter before them and have them pass a resolution to provide the necessary funds. If they refuse to do this, it can be taken as above stated from the capital at their credit.

If a new building is erected it would be necessary to obtain a new site, as the site on which the present school stands is too small and has no room for play-grounds. Mr. Kelly told me that a suitable site would be near the church and that he thought it could be obtained from Daniel Cusman, an Indian, by paying him a small amount for his improvements.

A request has been received for 32 new desks and Mr. Kelly stated that, if a new school building were erected, it would be well to wait until then before any new equipment is purchased.

There is no doubt, from the reports received from the Inspector and the Agent, that a new building is required and it appears to me that the Indians could very well consent to give the necessary amount from their funds. If you approve of this work being undertaken the Architect should prepare the necessary plans and Mr. Agent Robertson should be requested to take the steps necessary to obtain a new site and the consent of the band to provide the funds.

I may say that no accommodation would be required for the teacher in the new building, as the teacher could obtain board and lodging in the town of Nanaimo quite close to the school.

Regarding the ten children mentioned as residing on the Nanaimo River, five miles distant from the present school, Rev. Mr. Kelly stated that arrangements could be made, should a new school be erected, to have them transported to and from the school at a cost of $2.00 per day, and that the Indians should provide this from their funds.

I consider that they should also pay the full salary of the teacher.

RE: NANAIMO INDIAN DAY SCHOOL.

From correspondence on File 74675 it appears that the land at present occupied by the Nanaimo Indian Day School and the play grounds in connection therewith was granted to the Church of England mission by the Nanaimo Indians for day school purposes about the year 1886. In 1890 the school building was improved, the work being done by the Indians and the Department allowed $287.00. The Church of England discontinued their mission on the Nanaimo Reserve about the year 1892 and the school was closed for the following two years.

In 1894 the Methodist Church authorities applied for permission to use the building for school purposes. (See file 117008-5 Closed) With the consent of the Church of England authorities this was done and under the auspices of the Methodist Church a school has been continued at this point since that time.

In official letter of August 2, 1920, Mr. Agent Robertson recommends that the new day school on the Nanaimo Indian Reserve be erected on the present site which consists of a little over one acre. He further states that it would be advisable to purchase from the owner, Susan, the small lot adjoining the school site. As the present school site has been used for school purposes since the year 1886, it would not appear necessary to obtain any further title to this land, but, if it is decided to purchase the additional lot recommended by the agent, a quit claim deed should, no doubt, be obtained from the present owner.
