Agreement made in duplicate the day of A. D.

Between His Majesty King George the Fifth, represented by the Superintendent General of Indian Affairs of Canada (hereinafter called the Superintendent General);

AND Messrs. Warnock & Rogers,

of Port Alberni, B. C., (hereinafter called the Contractors).

The Contractors for themselves, their heirs, executors, administrators and assigns, agree to do in the most workmanlike manner all works and provide all the materials of the best kind shown in the drawings and described in the specifications marked "A" and "B" respectively and signed by the Contractors and to complete, furnish and hand over to the Superintendent General or to some person by him appointed for that purpose the,

erection of an Indian Day School at Nanaimo, B. C., Plan No. 457.

and all other work and labour incidental to and necessary for the entire completion thereof, whether specified or shown in the drawings or specifications or not, by the

First day of June A. D. 1931.

AND in consideration of the above agreement on the part of the Contractors the Superintendent General hereby agree to pay the said Contractors the sum of £48 thousand two hundred and ninety-three and 60/100 dollars, provided always that the Superintendent General may at any time during the progress or after the completion or alleged completion of the work appoint an Architect, Engineer or other officer, in which case the certificate of such Architect, Engineer or other officer, that the work is duly completed and of the amount herein described the Contractors after making such allowances for penalties and for defective or incomplete work, or for extras and deviations as the Architect, Engineer or other officer shall think fair, shall be a condition precedent to any claim by the Contractors under this contract.

AND the Contractors for themselves their executors, administrators and assigns, further covenant and agree:

1. That the wages to be paid in the execution of this contract shall be those generally accepted as current in each trade for competent workmen in the district where the work is carried on. If this condition is violated the Superintendent General may cancel the contract and refuse to accept any work done thereunder.

2. That if the Contractors fail at any time to pay any account for any goods or materials supplied, or money advanced by anyone to the said Contractors for the purposes of this agreement, or to pay the account of any sub-contractor for any work or materials done or supplied for the said works to be constructed under this agreement, and such
account is in either of such cases one month overdue, the Superintendent General may notify the Contractors to pay such account and if a week elapse and the same be not paid in full, the Superintendent General may pay such account and may charge the same to the Contractors, and the Contractors covenant with the Superintendent General to repay at once any and every sum so paid.

3. That if the Contractors fail at any time in paying salaries or wages of any person employed by them upon or in respect of the said works, or any of them, and any part of such salary is one month in arrear, or if there be due to any such person one month's wages or salary, the Superintendent General may notify the Contractors to pay such salary or wages, and if two days elapse and the same be not paid in full up to date of payment, or to such other date as may be in accordance with the terms of employment of such person, then the Superintendent General may pay to such person his salary or wages from any date to any date and to any amount which may be payable, and may charge the same to the Contractors and the Contractors covenant with the Superintendent General to repay at once any and every sum so paid.

4. That pursuant to the Statute in that behalf, this Agreement is made subject to the express condition that no member of the House of Commons of Canada shall be admitted to any share or part of this Agreement or any benefit to arise therefrom.

5. That the Contractors shall not assign, transfer or set over this contract or any interest therein to any person or persons whomsoever, without the consent, in writing, of the Superintendent General of Indian Affairs first had and obtained.

IN WITNESS WHEREOF the said Superintendent General of Indian Affairs, acting as aforesaid and the said Warnock & Rogers have hereunto set their hands and seals the day and year first above mentioned.

Sir,

I beg to report that the contractors have finished the excavation at the above School and are engaged putting in the Concrete. This work will be complete by Friday next Feb 18th.

I examined the foundation on Feb 8th before allowing the Concrete footing to be put in. The whole foundation is hard pan the excavation clay. It will be necessary to put a weeping drain around the building as the sub soil is non porous.

I have asked the Contractors to give me a tender for 4" tile weeping drain around the building. Said drain to discharge into the river - a distance of 250 feet (inclusive of building) I shall submit tender to the Dept. of Rafter, Studs, joists, Shiplap, and V joint as now on the job and of No 1 Standard.

3 Carpenters, 7 Labourers, and 2 Steamfitters.
The Contractors, aiming to finish this work
by the end of April.

I am staying here until about March 25th,
when I shall proceed to Fraser Lake, to value the
amount of work done, and give the Contractor a
Certificate accordingly, also inform the Dept. the
amount that will be figured to the end of March.
(end of financial year). I shall then return
to headquarters to see this work completed, after
which I proceed to Fraser Lake for the carrying out
of that work.

I understand from the Contractor, Mr.

very little work is being done there now.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 31st ultimo, enclosing copy of a communication from Miss Klappert, teacher of the Namismo Indian Day School, in which she requests that an organ be supplied for the use of the school, and states that she can obtain a second hand one for the sum of $20.

In reply I beg to say that it is not the policy of the Department to supply organs for the use of Indian day schools, and it is, therefore, regretted that it will not be possible to comply with the teacher's request. The usual procedure to obtain this equipment at day schools is to raise the money required by holding concerts, and I would suggest that the teacher use this method in the raising of the amount required for the purchase of the organ.

When I first took over the Indian boys at the Nanaimo Reserve for technical work, I noted that physically they were in poor shape. However, I organized a football team and in a short time an marked improvement was very evident.

Last year we won the School League Shield open to the district.

Of course, you will readily understand that there is some expense incurred which has been met by the boys &c.

As the boys are not ready to fit this year, it has been a trying season. But I intend to carry on, to get out some support in the way of a football. I also want eleven hostages for the winners. Cheap ones will do and I will be pleased.
to pay half the cost out of my own pocket.

They could be purchased much cheaper in Eastern Canada, just small silver ones will do.

The boys are bright, mentally alert, and I can guarantee they will make good citizens.

The work they do is quite advanced.

We have built a house, two a lool,

and hot air engines and etc.

If you would like more photos will only be too pleased to send them.

Mr. Evans, the Inspector suggested my writing you direct.

Yours very faithfully

John G. Macdonald

We will be quite pleased with second hand tools anything that is hirable.

Sir:

Mr. Ditchburn, Indian Commissioner for B. C., wired you some days ago in regard to transportation of Indian children from Nanaimo River Reserve to No.1, Reserve to attend school, and on which the Department was good enough to grant $45.00 for one month's transportation.

I might point out that for many years these Indian children have had the privilege of riding on coal train to and from school, a distance of about five miles, recently owing to the market for coal being in a bad state the Coal Company have had to discontinue their operations, and it was thought that the children should be transported to the school.

It is questionable indeed if the Company will again commence operations within a month and I would ask for authority to further engage the Indian, Paul White should it be necessary.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 25th ultimo in further reference to the request of the teacher of the Nanaimo Indian Day School to be supplied with paper towelling, liquid soap and toilet paper.

In reply I have to say that it is not the practice of the Department to supply equipment of this nature for use in Indian day schools. Sir:

The Department wishes to have a report on the work of the Indian Chief Paul White, who brings ten or eleven of the children from the Nanaimo River reserve to the Nanaimo Indian Day School. Mr. Inspector Barry reports that 9 out of a possible 11 were present from this outside reserve on the day of his visit and that this service is under the supervision of Dominion Constable O'Connell.

Dear Sir,

In compliance with your instructions, desiring a report relative to attendance of pupils from the River Reserve.

I may state that eleven children of school age only being available, on River Reservation, their attendance at school since being conveyed by car has been exceptionally good, as the enclosed report of the teacher Miss M. Ripert will substantiate.

Independent of my periodical visits to the school, I have caused Chief Paul White to make special (verbal) reports to me, names of children failing to attend and cause of their absence.

If not sick, or otherwise having no reasonable excuse, I at once confer with the parents, whom I have to a degree, warm up a little, occasionally.

But in the hole the question of attendance, taking into reasonable consideration, is about as near to the daily attendance of the children at the school, as conditions existing from time to time, that is unavoidable.

Remaining your obediently

(SGN.) Theo O'Connell.
Bom. Constable.
The average attendance for the eleven pupils from the Nanaimo River Reserve who are attending the Indian Bay School for the month of April was 6.75. During the month of May 9.04 some of the pupils were absent on account of sickness during the "flu" epidemic; otherwise the pupils have been very punctual and regular in their attendance.

The progress is very much more satisfactory, since the car has been in operation.

Previously the attendance was very irregular. Jerry Good one of the pupils, has been using his bicycle instead of the car, partly I think on account of family difficulties.

Hoping the present arrangements of transportation may continue satisfactory to all concerned.

S. Clippert,
Teacher.

Dear Senator Planta,

Following your visit to my office a few days ago, I communicated with the Indian agent at Duncan, B.C., regarding the service being given by Chief Paul White in transporting the Indian children from the Nanaimo River reserve to the Nanaimo Indian day school.

I am now in receipt of a reply from the Indian agent with which he encloses reports from the constable and the teacher of the school. The constable states that the attendance of these children at school since being conveyed by car has been exceptionally good. Chief White is required to give the constable a report of the non-attendance of any children for whom he is responsible stating the cause of absence. The teacher reports that the progress of the children is very much more satisfactory since the car has been in operation and she hopes this arrangement for transportation may continue.

It would appear that the Chief is giving good service and that the arrangement is proving satisfactory.

Yours very truly,

Hon. Albert F. Planta,

Kamloops, B.C., June 17th, 1931.

Dear Sir:

Cowichan Agency Inspection Report No. 1.

I visited the Day School at Nanaimo No. 1 Reserve and met Miss Clifford, the teacher. There were twenty-two in class on the day of my visit and the school was well kept and well run.

I visited the Day School at Comiaken, where the teacher, Mrs. Roe, was mistress. There was only one child in class. She informed me that all the other children had accompanied their parents to the berry picking in the U.S.A.

I visited the Koksailah Day school, Miss Cleff in charge. There were nine children in attendance and everything seemed very satisfactory.

I also visited the Songees Reserve Day school. There were nine children in attendance, and everything there was also quite satisfactory.

In connection with these day schools, I should recommend that they all have cheap aluminum or enamel cups provided, upon which the children's names could be marked, and the children instructed to use individual mugs. This has been done at many other day schools, and is a good preventative from T.B. infection.

Geo. S. Pragnell,
Inspector of Indian Agencies.

An All-Cast Furnace with Powerful Heating Capacity

THE new "Series 700" Hecla has been specially built by Clare Bros. to meet the growing demand for a thoroughly high-grade, all-cast furnace. Every part is heavy and strong, made for a long life of service.

Return Flue Radiator

The "Series 700" Hecla differs from all other all-cast furnaces in that it has what is termed a return flue radiator, with both direct and indirect fire travel. The radiator here illustrated is placed around a particularly large and heavy combustion chamber. It is deep and narrow with a
The illustration above shows the deep cup joint joining the radiator to the combustion chamber. These same deep cup joints are used throughout the construction of the furnace.

division plate that gives long fire travel twice the length of any other all-cast furnace thus making every square inch of the radiator an effective heat radiating surface. Because this feature has the effect of doubling the distance the fire has to travel before it reaches the smoke pipe, it practically makes the heat from the firepot do double duty. It means more heat going to the house and less up the smoke pipe or the work done with less fuel.

The heavy return flue radiator is a very important part of the equipment of this new furnace and will appeal strongly to the purchaser who seeks a massive, rugged furnace with large heating capacity combined with unusual economy in operation. - Holes in furnace front for water coil connections for domestic water supply.
- An all-cast specially designed combustion chamber.
- Extra wood grate to convert the Hecla into a wood burning furnace when required.

It also has the full regular equipment—check dampers complete with chains, pulleys, etc., poker and scraper. Pages 14 to 19 give full descriptions of these special Hecla features.

During the latter part of last term the furnace in the Nanaimo Indian Day School was giving considerable trouble, and the smoke coming into the class room so badly, Miss Klippert the teacher became alarmed and sent for a plumber who had to take the furnace all to pieces to find out what was wrong, and he found some of the castings broken.

I went up and examined it myself and found that considerable repairs were needed both on the furnace and the pipes, so I asked Mr. Bailey, who had taken it apart to give me an estimate on the repairs to the old furnace, and also on cost of a new one.

I have been running 6 miles round trip return. Two return trips comes to 24 miles that is one days work. At 5 schooling days in a week and in 1 month comes to 30 schooling days at 2 return trips a day comes to 40 trips a month which comes to $45. or a month it proves that all I have been getting was $1.12½ a day out of that sum I have been buying my own gas, oil,
wear and tear and also repairs by
the time I get through with all
this there is nothing left. In
fact I have been digging into my
own pocket. Now since I've been
on the job I found myself in debt
of over $100 or that is for oil and
repairs. Of course it was my
own offer at $45 a month as
I did not understand how much
it would take to run. When I
started on the job I found out
that is what we call a broken
day. That is to say when I
start off in the morning at 8:30 A.M.
get back at 9:30 A.M. and ready
to go down again at 2:30 P.M.
get back at 3:30 P.M. and the
day is short. So let us begin and not be miserable on the job.

I figure the present system honestly dealt with would be $3.00 a day comes to $60.00 a month in wages and out of that I buy oil and gas $15.00 allowed for repairs which will total $75.00 a month.

Figure as follows: 6 mi. way @ $5.00 return trip 12 mi. @ $1.50 for 2 return trips = $3.00 day schooling day comes to $3.00 5 days = $15.00 4 weeks 1 month comes to $60.00 wages Allowance for repairs is $15.00 month Total $75.00 month.

I hope you will find this quite
in order. Dear Mr Graham & wish you would kindly mention about that reduction of my salary to our government as I am not in position to pay it for I have a big family as you know my salary is small. After this holiday season when I start again I want to start very carefully so to get myself out of the hole providing that I must live. Wishing to thank you so much.

I remain
your obedient servant,

Sir:

When visiting Nanaimo recently Chief Paul White spoke to me about small amount that was allowed for transporting children from Nanaimo River Indian reserve to the Nanaimo Indian Day School. I told him to put his complaint in writing, which he has done, I enclose copy herewith.

I might state that the Chief has done good conscientious work in carrying these children backwards and forwards, and I know that he has certainly not made much money out of it. The Nanaimo Indian Day school is certainly a credit, and it is largely due to the Chief transporting these children that such regular attendance is kept up, and I would like to recommend that if it is at all possible, that he be granted an increase for this work.

Your obedient servant,

(H. Graham)

Dear Mr. Graham:

In answer to your letter of the 17th inst., I wish to explain why it is necessary to have paper towels and liquid soap rather than the ordinary roller towelling.

This is to prevent the spread of infectious diseases, both the "children's diseases" and skin diseases. When twenty children or more use the same towel and the same cake of soap, and if one child should be contracting measles or some other communicable disease there is grave danger that the other nineteen children would develop measles, getting the infection direct from the towel.

Most of the infectious diseases are caused by germs and these germs are transmitted in the nose and mouth discharges and therefore by the hands; therefore it is most important that each child has his own towel.

In the case of "impetigo" or any of the skin diseases it is more important that other children do not dry on the same towel as the child with the disease, for these diseases are very infectious.

During our last session of "impetigo" fortunately when we had the first cases there were still some paper towels and liquid soap left, so the disease has not spread a great deal. Since the supply has come to an end we have had the few remaining cases use newspaper, instead of cloth towels to prevent it spreading any further.

After the first five cases of impetigo, when it was found that there had been only four new cases. If the community towel had been used the number of cases would have been greatly increased.

The children with impetigo have been kept at school as it was found that when they stayed at home the parents would not give the treatment regularly, and the conditions did not clear up. With daily treatment at the school the "sores" have disappeared in a comparatively short time.

I hope it will be possible to renew the supply of paper towels and green soap. We already have the containers for the latter.

Sincerely yours,

(Signed) Muriel Upshall.
Sir:

In the last requisition forwarded to the Department for supplies for the Nanaimo Indian Day School, they requisitioned for liquid soap and paper towels, and I received a reply stating that these were not supplied.

I might state that this same controversy took place just a year ago, and the late Commissioner Mr. Ditchburn ordered these as well as instructing me to get containers for the soap, which are of course on hand at present.

I might state that there has been considerable trouble in this school with different children diseases, and it was for this reason that the district nurse recommended these and I now enclose copy of letter just received from the Nurse on the subject.

I sincerely trust that the Department will be able to see its way clear to grant these.

Your obedient servant,

(H. Graham)
Indian Agent.

Sir:

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your telegram of the 10th instant, regarding the water supply at the Nanaimo Indian Day School. It is noted that, after investigating the trouble, it was found the water pipe had become completely corroded throughout and that new pipe is required. In this connection I have to confirm the following night lettergram to you of today's date:—

"May purchase, from firm on approved list, new pipe required for water system, Nanaimo School. Keep costs installing pipe, digging and filling low as possible. Use Indian labour as far as possible."

It is noted that the quantity of pipe required will cost approximately $184.00 and that, besides, there will be the cost of digging and filling the trench in which the pipe is installed. Further, it is presumed, there will be the cost of investigating the trouble.

As our funds are extremely limited, the Department has to request that you will see that all costs in placing the water system at this school in good condition are kept down to the lowest possible point. It is hoped that you can use Indian labour for the work of digging and filling.

After the new pipe has been installed, to your satisfaction, and the water supply at the school placed in good condition, you should forward accounts, in triplicate, properly certified, covering the expenditure incurred in the purchase of the pipe and for the labour in having it installed.

Sir:

When visiting the Nanaimo Indian Reserve yesterday my attention was drawn to the sewer pipe leading from the toilets in the Indian Day School. When this school was built this pipe was taken out into the water of the sea but a recent storm has broken the pipe off just above high water mark with the result that the deposit from the toilets is being left on the beach where water never reaches and is causing a terrific stench. This will necessitate a new four inch iron pipe being added to the present line and being properly protected from the sea. I think this can be done for about $30.00 and I would like to have permission to attend to this immediately.

Your obedient servant,

Ottawa, November 6, 1936.

Dear Sir:

In reviewing the return of the Nanaimo Indian Day School for the month of September, it is noted that, while there is an enrolment of 24 pupils, there was only an average attendance of 19. This is considered rather low in view of the fact that the Department is allowing $50 a month for transporting the pupils to school.

Please let me know at once whether or not Chief Paul White is performing his duties in a satisfactory manner. You should also state the average attendance during the month of October.

H. Graham, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Duncan, B.C.
Sir:

In reply to yours of the 6th instant, regarding attendance at the Nanaimo Indian Day School, on which you make comment on the average attendance for the month of September last, I might say that during this month there was nearly 100% attendance for those that were on the reserve; there were some children who came at the beginning of the month and were then taken away by their parents when they left for the saltery.

During the month of October the average attendance was 95%, which was also really very good, as there were 12 children still away at the salteries, and there are also old children away sick.

The work performed by Chief Paul White in transporting the children from the River Reserve to the school is quite satisfactory.

April 12th, 1937.

Sir:

I beg to enclose herewith voucher No. 1268 for $25.42 in favor of J. H. Bailey covering emergency work done at Nanaimo Indian Day School.

In connection with above, I may say last Summer on visiting the Nanaimo Indian Day School I found the toilets had blocked, and there was such a stench, Mr. Bailey was instructed to fix it. In the Fall on visiting this school again I found the school room filled with smoke and on examining the furnace found the pipes were badly worn and they were letting the smoke up through the radiators, and I considered it dangerous and I asked Mr. Bailey to put it right. I had no idea and he did not report to me that there was so much work needed, only on receipt of his bill did I know that all this work was required, but he states that the furnace was in such a condition that it could not work without the repairs being done immediately, thus the reason my application was not made for permission to have the work done.

Trusting the Department will approve of this expenditure.

Dear Sir:

We have recently received a letter written by Mr. L. F. Lepas, 430 Stewart Avenue, Nanaimo, B. C., in which he states that the following repairs are required to the Nanaimo Indian Day School:

"Repairs are badly needed to stairways, gutters, rain conductor pipes, windows and verandah. The ventilator also requires some attention, as during rainy spells from certain quarters the rain beats through ventilator (having wooden vanes) and thereby soaking ceiling and causing unnecessary damage to the ceiling which is quite noticeable, and if allowed to remain in this condition will cause a greater amount of damage than if properly repaired between now and school opening in the fall."

You will remember that in official letter of April 26 you were advised that an amount of $400.00 was available for repairs and improvements at the five Day Schools in the Cowichan Agency. Extract from Inspector Barry's report on the Nanaimo Day School dated May 27, 1938.

EXD.

Many repairs to the school are necessary, and a new hot air coal burning furnace will be required before school opening in September. At present the smoke gets into the classroom as the lining of the furnace is worn out and broken. Possibly the Acting Indian agent would be able to let you know just what the required new furnace would cost. The hot air pipes if cleaned out would not need to be replaced as they are in good condition in general.

In general the Nanaimo Indian Day School building needs many repairs, but quite good work is being done in the classroom by Miss Creighton and the children.

I am informed by the teacher that the Acting Agent wishes me to report on the damage to the school buildings, and certain other matters with regard to the buildings.

The school is located on what I may term a Village Green. The older ex pupils and Indian youths who are idle should be kept off this ground around the school till after school hours. They interfere with the school if it is in session or if the teacher is taking Drills etc. outside.

Though strong wire mesh was placed on the school windows this was not sufficient. A number have been broken by the balls used in Box Lacrosse played on the field in which the school is located. Very heavy strong wire guards are needed now for the windows which I hope may be mended during the summer vacation. Several pieces of glass will be needed.
The steps to the school porch on the Boys' side need repair.

The inside of the school is in need of kalsomine. The furnace is not worth repairing and will need to be renewed this summer if school is to be held in the room as at present smoke makes its way into the room. There is a fine clean basement with a hot air pipe furnace. The pipes will need to be cleaned out but they can be used again. The coal burning furnace is not worth repairing. No doubt the Indian Agent will be able to report on the estimated cost of the necessary repairs.

Repairs are also needed to the doors of the school.

(Sgd.) Gerald H. Barry
Inspector of Indian Schools, B. C.

Dear Sir:

Some time ago it was brought to my notice that Chief Paul Whyte, who transports the Nanaimo School Children from Nanaimo Indian Reserves, 2, 3 & 4 to Reserve No. 1, where the Indian Day School is located, did not go to all the reserves to pick up the children in the morning or in the afternoon when he brought them back from School, but made them walk across the railway trestle bridge across the river to his house where they got into his car.

As soon as I found out that this situation existed I immediately instructed Paul Whyte that he would have to go to the reserves in question and pick them up at or near their own homes, and return them there after School. Apparently the original agreement was made with the thought in mind of keeping down the cost, but if one of the children ever fell off the bridge or got killed by a train while crossing it would certainly not be economy from the point of view of the Department, and what a scandal it would cause.

With the additional mileage that Whyte has to travel daily to pick up and deliver these children, it is not fair that he should be expected to do it for the price of $60.00 which he is receiving at present. His car must be in good condition and he should carry accident Insurance. He travels a distance of 32 miles daily, or a total of approximately 756 miles monthly, and at 13¢ per mile which is a reasonable charge, the price should be approximately $110.00 monthly. However, I would not advise this much, but would recommend an amount of $80.00 per month or 23 school days. If this is agreed on I would also recommend that he be made to take out Accident and personal liability insurance.

I might say that I discussed this matter with Inspector's Coleman & Barry when they were in this Agency last month, and took them over the route which the Chief is now having to travel. I would recommend that this rate apply as from January 3rd, instant, as Whyte has been making the extra mileage ever since late in November last.

Yours Obediently,

D. M. MacKay, Esq.,
Indian Commissioner for B. C.,
Vancouver, B. C.,

Sir,

During a recent visit to the Nanaimo Indian Day School I found that the Teacher had not received all the articles she requested in the Requisition submitted last December. I refer to Drano for the water pipes, Plunger for the toilet, as without it the system seems to keep blocking up, and toilet paper. I might add that these items were again asked for in the Requisition submitted just before the Easter holidays, and while the authority has not yet been received it is not possible to wait any longer.

Owing to the fact that this was an emergency, I authorised the purchase of 3 tins of Drano, 1 plunger and 1 doz. rolls of toilet paper. If this had not been attended to it is reasonable to expect that the whole plumbing system at the school might block up and would be an expensive job putting it in working order again. I trust my action in this matter will be approved.

I also found that the chimneys in the school are very dirty and require cleaning very badly. Generally this job is put off until the summer holidays but they seem to be dirtier this year than usual and need it very badly now. Apart from the dirty condition of the chimneys and furnace pipes, which I might add will also have to be cleaned at the same time, there is quite a serious fire hazard with the chimney's in the condition they are in at the moment. Kindly authorise this expenditure at your early convenience. The same price that has been charged in other years will prevail again this year, as the work is done by the City of Nanaimo Chimney Sweep.

Yours obediently;

The Secretary;

Mines & Resources.
Ottawa.

Dear Sir:

I beg to submit herewith for your consideration and recommendation a Requisition covering necessary repairs to the Nanaimo Indian Day School. Most of these repairs have been asked for at some time or other during the past few years but for one reason or another always got passed up.

There is not one item mentioned on this Requisition that is not badly needed, but particular reference should be made to moving of the boys' toilet from downstairs in the basement to the boys' washroom and entrance upstairs.

This matter has been referred to me several times during the past year by the Medical Officer in charge of the Reserve, as well as the Nurse. There is absolutely no ventilation in the toilet and its location is wrong for a school because it makes supervision almost impossible.

You will remember during our recent visit to the Nanaimo Indian Day School that the question of light in the School was discussed with the teacher.

It was thought that if the ceiling of the class room could be painted a light colour that it would improve the particularly poor light which exists in that School during dark days.

I got an estimate of the cost of material and labour necessary for this and which I quote below:

4 gals paint @ $4.50 per gal $18.00

$35.00

Dear Mr. Mayhew:

Re: Indian School--Nanaimo Reserve.

I do not know if Mr. Alan Chambers is in Ottawa at present or not, so thought I would write you direct in case he is not there.

I examined the "Indian School" today and find that several matters require attention. I discovered a number of broken windows, some sashes would not open and others were minus sash cords. It is necessary that windows open freely for the proper ventilation of class room.

A window ventilator should be build on inner wall of class room for proper ventilation. This window could be opened for closed as required and could be opened or closed by attaching a cord to same.

It appears the school requires painting on outside and class room should receive some attention, as well as Trellis work in and around outside stairs.

Three years ago Mr. Chambers had the Department of Indian Affairs carry out suggestions which I made at that time, and I believe it would be considered good business to carry out suggestions contained herein by this summer; if left longer it would prove much more costly.

I mention these matters for what they are worth and hope the improvements will be carried out.

With kindest personal regards,

Sir:

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 28th March, with attached copies of letters in connection with the present condition of the Nanaimo Indian Day School.

It is quite true that certain repairs were made to this school during the latter part of 1940 and during the fiscal year just closed, enough I thought for one year and all that we could reasonably expect and also all that was actually needed. I also included an amount of $125.00 in my estimates for that school for further repairs during the current Fiscal year. With reference to the ventilation of the school and the necessity for the new window ventilator, I might say that this school has got along for the past twenty years with the ventilation system as it exists at present so there is no reason why it can't get along for another year or two if necessary, at all events this is not serious. The repairs to the windows can and will be done as soon as the money is available but in the interval nonseems getting hurt and there is really nothing serious the matter, in fact the school is in much better condition than some of the white schools right in Nanaimo City. I have been instructed times without number that I was not to ask for anything during the war that we could get along without, and I certainly think that the ventilation of a school that has been operating for over 20 years can continue to function satisfactorily for another year or two if necessary. Painting will be carried out this year, if funds are provided.

Under date of March 4th, ultimo I was instructed by the Department in their letter No. 57-152 to have Mr. Layes Insure this school for a period of three years and in my letter to him I asked him to look over the building to see if the risk could be reduced. In due time I received his reply which went forward to the Department under date of March 25th, with covering letter from myself. This explains why Mr. Layes did not consider it necessary to visit this Reserve.

However, you have brought up a very important point in connection with the general public visiting Indian houses without permission from units of the same day schools, and your comments are noted regarding the practice in eastern Canada. It is only a matter of time that I took this question up with the Department in the office of the Indian Commissioner, asking that steps be taken to take necessary action under the Indian Act for the protection of our Indians. But I was informed verbally by Major Macdonald that it was considered wise as it might tend to attract publicity to the Trespasser, and although I reported under date of last on this matter I have not yet received a reply or recommendation from the department. My consideration is that the general public in this Province trespass where they please on our Reserves and there is nothing about it; largely because we know nothing about it and it is all over.

Yours obediently,

The Secretary,

Mines & Resources,
Ottawa.

I am listing the repairs in the order in which they should be done depending on their importance at this time.

- Labor stripping & shingling @ 3.00 = 72.00
- 12 gallons of shingle stain @ 1.85 = 22.20
- Labor staining roof @ 2.00 = 28.00

$215.68

The exterior of the school is badly in need of painting, owing to the proximity of the building to the salt water the paint has almost all gone off, especially on the sea side, and the lumber is becoming damaged. The cost of this work follows:
- 12 gallons of paint @ $4.20 = $50.40
- Labor charge for painting @ 8.60 = 88.60

$139.00

AIR MAIL

Dear Sir:

I beg to forward herewith a copy of a letter received from Mr. Indian Agent Moore regarding the transportation of Indian children living on the Nanaimo River Indian Reserve to and from the Nanaimo Indian Day School.

In the last paragraph of Mr. Moore's letter he refers to this matter as having been discussed with Dr. McGill during the brief visit the Director made to Chief Paul White. It is true that this subject was brought up by Chief White at the time but I do not recall Dr. McGill passing any opinion as to what he considered the rate of payment should be or making a decision in the matter.

Inspector Barry considers that $125.00 per month is high since it provides for the transportation of not more than fourteen children and in this I am inclined to agree with him. In January, 1940, Mr. Moore wrote to this office pointing out that Chief White could not continue to operate his bus for the amount then allowed and suggested a monthly rate of $110.00, or approximately 15¢ per mile, the mileage travelled being approximately 736 miles per month. This rate would not be excessive for the service rendered and would be in line with what the Department is paying for the transportation of the children attending the St. Catherine's School.

As it would be out of the question to make other arrangements that would be as satisfactory at any less cost, I would recommend that $110.00 per month be

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines & Resources,
Ottawa, Ont.
allowed for the current school year and that the matter of transportation at this school be reviewed this coming summer or immediately following the close of the term in June.

With reference to the second paragraph of Mr. Moore's letter, there is no information on file here which would indicate that the Department agreed to assume responsibility for the payment of such insurance but it is possible that the Department may have had some correspondence with Mr. Moore on the subject of which we have no record. Such protection is, however, considered necessary and as Chief White is unable financially to meet the costs himself, the Department might consider doing so for this year at least, or until such time as better arrangements can be made.

I should appreciate the Department's decision in these matters at an early date.

Yours faithfully,

D.M. MacKay,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.

/GR
Dear Sir:

With reference to previous correspondence and our discussions regarding the transportation for the Nanaimo Indian school children, I wish to advise that Johnny White, son of the Chief, succeeded in getting his "Class A Drivers License" and is fully qualified to drive a school bus. He has also made arrangements to buy a G.M.C. School Bus, capacity 14, at a price of $915.00. This car has been inspected by the Police and found very satisfactory; it is a 1939 Model and in perfect mechanical order. He got an allowance of $300.00 for his old car which leaves a balance of $615.00 to pay which he must do at the rate of $50.00 per month. White's License No. is 207.

He has arranged to take out the necessary insurance covering the bus insofar as theft, fire or accident to the car itself is concerned. However, there is the Public Liability and Property damage Insurance which this Department tentatively agreed to pay and which will amount to a premium of $47.60 per year. However, as we do not use the bus for a year we can apply at the end of the school term—next June—for a refund of one-sixth of the premium. This Policy is being sent to Ottawa by the Insurance Agent direct as we must have coverage commencing next Wednesday and it is going forward Air-Mail this afternoon, with a letter of explanation from the Insurance Agent.

You will remember that during the visit of the Director, yourself and I to the Chief the question of Salary was mentioned and $125.00 per month was asked. Dr. McGill did not think that amount was too much and I was of the opinion that he would recommend payment at that rate. Actually, when we take into consideration the cost of gas, oil, tires and any necessary repairs nowadays this does not leave very much for the operator when he pays $50.00 per month for the Bus. It amounts to less than 15¢ per mile which is less than half what we are paying for the Cowichan Bus. I would recommend that this matter receive immediate attention and that the above suggested arrangements be made. You might please advise me by telephone not later than Tuesday morning next so that I may make the necessary arrangements for the bus to be in use the following day.

Yours obediently,

Major D.M. MacKay,
Vancouver, B.C.

Extract from Inspector Barry's letter to Major MacKay dated October 27, 1941.

The transportation of children from the Nanaimo River Indian Reserve by bus continues. I consider the sum allowed this year for this service, $110.00 a month, very liberal indeed. The teacher acting on Departmental instructions is keeping a record of the number of children transported daily. The average for the twelve days on which the bus has been operated this month so far is as mentioned in my report under 7 per day. I asked her to urge these children to attend regularly and I spoke to the children themselves and told them that the bus cost a considerable sum and that if attendance was not good it would have to be discontinued. I made a point of being at the school at 8:50 a.m. but did not see the bus driver as he had reached the school this morning at 8:35 a.m. He should arrange to reach the school just before 9 a.m. and make certain he has not left pupils behind by being too early in starting from the River Reserve.

Dear Sir:

During a recent visit to the Nanaimo Indian Day School the condition of the steps outside the school and leading up to the doors was brought to my attention. These steps need new stringers and it is thought that there is enough lumber, odd pieces in the right sizes, available in the manual training building and that is not being used for anything else that could be utilized for that purpose. This would save buying any extra material and the pieces I speak of have been on hand for some considerable time so that we might as well make use of them.

The Manual Training Instructor could do the work but he would have to take another day—or maybe a day and a half to do the job properly—and for which we would be called upon to pay him at the same rate as we pay for his daily services, once a week, viz., $7.00

The work is of a nature that the boys of the school could not be employed at, as they are quite small and would only be in the way.

The labor for the entire job should not take more than $10.00 and I would recommend that approval be given for this work to be undertaken as soon as possible.

Yours obediently;

D.M. MacKay, Esq.,
Indian Commissioner for B. C.
Vancouver, B. C.

Dear Sir:-

I beg to forward herewith a copy of a letter received from Mr. Indian Agent Moore making application for authority to expend the sum of $10.00 to have the steps at the entrance of the Nanaimo Indian Day School repaired.

I would recommend favourable consideration of the application and would appreciate the Department's decision at an early date.

Yours faithfully,

Dear Sir:

I beg to attach hereto in duplicate a copy of a letter received from Mr. R.M. Ormond, Nanaimo B.C., regarding certain necessary repairs to the furnace of the Nanaimo Indian Day School.

It has been three years, or will be next winter, since any repairs were made to this furnace and on one of my recent visits to the school I noticed that some of the pipes needed attention as they were breaking away at the joints. I therefore asked Mr. Ormond to inspect the furnace and let me know just what was required to put the plant in first class operating condition again.

I included the sum of $100.00 in the Estimates for repairs to the Nanaimo School and trust that this work can be attended to before the summer holidays commence, as I don't like the idea of the school being open at all during the holidays, for any reason, as there is always something missing or broken afterwards and no one will accept the responsibility. I would therefore recommend that the work be attended to and that it be done before school closes at the end of June.

Dear Sir:

Please refer to your above noted letter with reference to the painting of the Nanaimo Indian Day School. In this regard I beg to advise that I called on the firm of Walls & Bradshaw to make arrangements for them to proceed with the work as soon as conveniently possible. I left a copy of the original Requisition with the firm and explained how the accounts should be submitted upon completion of the work etc. and returned to Headquarters.

Some days later I received a letter regarding the matter which explains that an error had been made in submitting the original estimate, probably by our own Manual Training Instructor, who did not give the measurements of the building and misinterpreted the labor charge mentioned. However, I discussed the matter with the firm again over the telephone and I find that provision for the porches, steps, basement door and windows had not been made in estimating the required amount of materials, which will amount to $650 more than quoted the first time, or a total of $400.00. The labor costs will run almost twice that amount or a total of $700.00. These costs, I might say are in keeping with prices which have been quoted to me in Duncan, in fact about $15.00 less.

Under the circumstances, I am sending herewith a copy of two letters in duplicate which I trust will be self explanatory. I would respectfully request that the matter be referred to the Department with a view to finding out if I may have the work done at the new price quoted.

Yours obediently,

D.M. MacKay, Esq.,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.
P.O. Box 70,
Vancouver, B.C.

AIR MAIL

Dear Sir:

I desire to refer to your letter of October 1, 1941, and official reply of October 4, 1941, approving, temporarily, the expenditure of an amount of $110.00 a month for transportation of children to the Nanaimo Indian Day School. We do not appear to have received any subsequent correspondence regarding this expenditure but yesterday we received an account for the transportation for the month of October, 1942. On reviewing the statement attached to the voucher it is found that on October 2 only 4 pupils were transported to the school and the largest number transported on any one day during the month was on October 14 when 11 children were carried. On the other days in the month the number transported varied between 4 and 11. The average attendance of pupils transported during the month was 8. Consequently the average cost was approximately $14.00 a pupil and at this rate the average cost per pupil for the academic year would be approximately $126.00 a pupil.

When you add to this figure the average cost of the teacher's salary, fuel and other expenses it is evident that it is more expensive to have these children educated at the Nanaimo Day School than it is in a residential school. I am, therefore, inclined to feel that the children from the Nanaimo River Indian Reserve should be enrolled in one of the residential schools and the expenditure for transportation discontinued at the end of the current month. However, as you are visiting the Cowichan Agency in connection with the St. Catherine's Day School, you may possibly have an opportunity of reviewing the situation at the Nanaimo School also. I will await your report with interest.

Yours truly,

Major D.M. MacKay,

Vancouver, B.C.

CRIME REPORT

Re: Rex Vs WHITE, John - Section 130 Indian Act -
Possession of an Intoxicant -

On Sunday December 13th, 1942 information was received that a booze party was in progress at the home of the above named Indian at the Nanaimo Indian Reserve. A search warrant was obtained by the undersigned from Stipendiary Magistrate C.H. Beever-Potts, and a patrol was made to the Nanaimo River Indian Reserve by Constables Stewart, Brassard & Tannock, to search for liquor.

On arrival at the White home at about 5:30 p.m. a search was made of the premises after the warrant to search was read to Mr. & Mrs. White, they stated no liquor was on the premises, after a search was made four quart bottles of Bohemian beer and ten pint bottles of Pilsner Lager beer were found on the premises. Gilbert White age 22 years and son of the above named was found in bed in a drunken condition. Also found on the premises were 8 dozen empty beer bottles.

John White was informed he would be charged with possession of liquor. The full and empty bottles were seized and taken to the Police Office as evidence. The above named was instructed to appear at 10:30 a.m. Monday December 14th, 1942 at Police Court in Nanaimo.

Gilbert White was arrested by the undersigned and brought to Nanaimo where he was locked up in the City Lock-Up charged with being in an intoxicated condition, see Crime Report submitted by the undersigned under the above date under the following heading;

Re: Rex Vs WHITE, Gilbert - Section 130 Indian Act

At 10:30 a.m. Monday December 14th 1942 the following information was laid by the undersigned before C.H. Beever-Potts, Stipendiary Magistrate,

"Who saith that John White on Sunday December 13th A.D. 1942 at Nanaimo River Indian Reserve in the County of Nanaimo, being an Indian of the Nanaimo Band, Unlawfully was in possession of an Intoxicant, to wit 10 pint bottles of Pilsner Lager Beer, four quart bottles of U.B.C. Bohemian Beer."

The accused appeared in person at the same time as the laying of the Information.

For the Prosecution S/Sergt. J. Russell
For the Defence The accused
Plea Guilty.

Questioned by the Magistrate as to where he obtained the liquor the accused stated his boy Gilbert had brought it home and stated when the boy gets drunk he cannot stop him from bringing liquor home, he admitted drinking some of it.

The presiding magistrate fined the accused $25.00 & $2.00 costs of the Court in default 14 days in gaol. The fine paid forthwith to the Clerk of the Peace Nanaimo, B.C. revenue receipt No. 43347 on file at this office. The costs paid forthwith to the presiding magistrate. In addition to the fine the magistrate ordered the liquor destroyed.

Sir,

This is to inform you that I met Inspector Coleman also again today. Chiefly to discuss the school bus transportation racket. I have shown their letter to my solicitor solicitor and he advised I was entitled to my collect. Surely I don't want to do that. Yes! I have been friends and I want to be friends with you forever. Johnny Whyte.

PUBLIC ARCHIVES ARCHIVES PUBLIQUES

CAJADA
Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. of Mines & Resources, Ottawa, Ont.

I would refer to your letter of November 11, 1942, file 152-11-5, regarding transportation costs of pupils of the Nanaimo Indian Day School.

In this connection, I would advise that there was no opportunity of visiting the school until the end of January and early in February when Mr. Inspector Coleman was making an inspection of the agency and discussed the problem with Mr. Indian Agent Moore and Johnny Whyte, Indian, who is the owner and driver of the school bus.

A Crime Report dated December 16th was received from the Provincial Police, copy of which is enclosed, stating that this Indian had been charged with possession of liquor on December 14th and fined $25.00 and costs for having intoxicants on his Reserve. This was referred to Agent Moore, as Johnny White was the driver of the school bus and trusted with the care of children and it was considered that the matter called for some consideration. Mr. Moore was requested to furnish me with his report and recommendations in the matter, and on December 29th last he advised that he had, on that date, informed this Indian not to continue transportation of the pupils until further advice. The driver remained in suspension for the month of January, during which month very little could have been done in any event as the roads were blocked with snow part of the time.

As the Indian was still paying for the cost of this school bus, I authorized Mr. Inspector Coleman to re-instate him on his visit to the agency if he considered it advisable in the interests of the safety of the children concerned. Following a discussion with Mr. Agent Moore and Johnny White, the Inspector agreed to the bus resuming service, commencing the first ultimo, its continuance pending a future decision of the Department contingent on an improved attendance by those pupils using this

P.T.O.
service, and also subject to this Indian not becoming further involved with the police and intoxicants. The responsibility for encouraging improvement in the school attendance was referred to Johnny Whyte.

This man showed some disposition to object to his suspension and claimed payment for the period, as will be seen from his letter enclosed, but I do not consider his representations should be entertained. He has two more payments to make on his car and some expense in connection with the purchase of his licence and insurance fees which may amount to $100.00.

I am now in receipt of a report for February and find that the daily average of the number of children conveyed is still only 8 pupils which works out at $13.75 per month or 68¢ per day for each pupil. While I do not entirely agree that these children could be educated at less cost at a residential School, as the Nanaimo Day School would, no doubt, continue to operate, I do feel that the costs are too high for the distance travelled and that unless there is a marked improvement by the end of the term that the service might be discontinued.

D.M. MacKay,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.

Dear Sir:

Indian School, Nanaimo

As requested we have made a thorough inspection of the furnace in the Indian School, Nanaimo Indian Reserve.

The furnace itself is in fair repair and to put same in good order we would recommend dismantling and recementing same. This is a cast iron sectional furnace and the sections are sealed with furnace cement and should be reset periodically. As the furnace is roughly handled, it requires resetting more often than the average furnace. A shaker handle is also required for the furnace. Grates are in good repair and when the fire box is thoroughly cleaned they will work freely. At present a horse shoe is lodged between two grates locking same.

Ducts, both hot air and cold air returns are in poor repair. We would recommend installing two new hot air runs as the existing ones are all of the light tin type and have been badly battered. Cold air ducts should be straightened out and resealed. Smoke pipe is in poor shape and should be replaced.

To carry out the above work and place heating plant in good repair, the cost would be Seventy-Eight Dollars and Fifty Cents ($78.50).

Respectfully submitted,

H. B. Ormond

Further to my letter of the 11th instant regarding the furnace at the Nanaimo Indian Day School I beg to attach herewith in duplicate a letter received from the plumbers in Nanaimo regarding the condition of the furnace and their recommendation that a new one be installed at a total cost of $205.00.

As this is the second furnace in schools which we have had burn out on us this year I tried to get information as to the possible cause from the heating contractors and they tell me that so far as they can find out the principal cause has been the use of poor coal during the last few years and in the case of this furnace in particular, old age. As the furnace can not be lighted at all it is very likely that the school will have to close unless the weather warms up very noticeably within the next few days. I have just been informed that the grates and fire-box in the furnace of the Nanaimo Indian Day School have burned through and the furnace can not function as it is. During a visit to the Nanaimo Indian Day School just before school closing I found that one of the side doors got broken from the outside after school hours; the exact reason not known although it is surmised that it was accidentally damaged by some of the young men of the Reserve practising lacrosse on the school grounds, one of them getting body checked into the lower panel of the door. It was nailed up overnight and a new door put on the following day by the manual training instructor, as well as two panes of glass for two windows which were also broken on two different occasions.

This was an emergency and I ordered the door and glass immediately so that access could not be gained to the school during the first part of the holidays or until I could receive the necessary authority. Re: Nanaimo River I.R.'s. Nos. 2 and 3,
School-age Children.

During a recent visit to the above reserves a strong protest was made to me about lack of school facilities for these children. I reviewed the indifference of the parents to the facilities provided by the Department some years ago, to which they admitted, but say that it will not happen again.

The present set-up on these Reserves, at present, is as follows:

1) Ten (10) children of school age.
2) No accommodation for them at the white Public School, at Cedar.
3) Nanaimo School Board has not, so far, consented to our children, from the River Reserves, travelling by their bus into Nanaimo to attend our own school on the Number 1 Indian Reserve.
4) I can get a Taxi Company, in Nanaimo, to transport our children to the Indian School in the a.m. and take them home in the p.m., at a flat daily rate of five dollars ($5.00). This is a much better plan -- but more expensive than the Nanaimo School Bus, owing to the fact that our own bus would pick up the children right on the Reserve, whereas the regular school bus does not leave the Highway, which, in the case of at least four of the children, would entail a one and one-half (1½) mile walk to the Highway and the same distance back. This is a long way in wet and stormy weather and, no doubt, would result in irregular attendance. However, if we are going to give these children an education it is going to cost approximately one hundred dollars ($100.00) per month for transportation only, and that is not on a per capita basis, but on a flat daily rate -- which I would recommend be considered.

R. H. Moore
Indian Agent.

In reply to your letter, date and file number above noted, I would advise that I visited the Nanaimo Indian Day School yesterday and went over the list of pupils with Mrs. Hill and this is what I found:

28 pupils at present in school,
16 pupils still to come, when they return from the United States and fishing grounds,
1 pupil from Nanaimo River already in attendance and included in the 28. (He rides his bicycle to and from school daily),
9 pupils on the River Reserves still to provide accommodation for, including transportation.

As you will see from the foregoing, there will be a total of 53 children who should be in school. The school building can not accommodate any more than 36 at the outside, although we have had more in it but it was too crowded.

The set-up which we may reasonably expect is:

40 to 53 pupils in attendance every day — which is far too many for one teacher and a one room school. At least 10 or 12 of these are beginners this year. Family Allowances are responsible for the children starting school earlier than under the Indian Act and Indian parents are becoming more educational conscious, particularly the younger married people — the result being a better feeling toward school which makes for better attendance.

It is obvious from the foregoing that something has to be done to provide education for the Nanaimo children and I should like to submit, below, a list of suggestions which may have some merit.

1) Open a room in the present Manual Training building (which used to be a school) for Grades 1 and 2 and put in a separate teacher.

2) As Manual Training is taught one day a week only, move benches and tools down to the basement of the present school where it could be carried on in a pinch.

3) If the two previous suggestions are accepted, the installation of electric lights, in both buildings, becomes a necessity.

4) If the first two are not looked upon with favour then open an extra school room in the basement of the Church, which the Indians use as a Church Hall, providing, of course, that the Indians would agree — which I am not so sure of.

5) If the first suggestion is accepted, then some repairs will have to be made to the Manual Training room before any pupils could be moved in there. Pending this, and if a teacher is available, I believe that two of them could carry on for awhile in the school, as at present, but I should like to talk that, as well as my other proposals, over with Major Davey on the ground.
In conclusion, I may say that Mrs. Hill is unable to do justice to herself, or the children, if she has more than 36.

R. H. MOORE
Indian Agent

Establishment of a second classroom at the Nanaimo Indian Day School.

Mr. W.S. Arneil, Indian Commissioner,

We are in receipt of Major MacKay's letter of January 16th, file 3-11-3, with reference to providing transportation of Indian children of the Nanaimo River Reserves.

In Indian Agent Moore's letter of September 10th which was forwarded to us under cover of Major MacKay's letter of November 21st, it was stated that there are ten children of school age on the Nanaimo River Reserves. No information was given regarding the distances that these children reside from the school. Educational authorities throughout Canada agree that children under ten years should be able to walk two miles each way to school daily and children over that age should be able to walk three miles each way daily. If the children reside within the distances just mentioned, it should not be necessary to supply transportion for them.

Transportation at the rate of $5.00 a day means approximately $100.00 a month which appears high for the number of children involved. Is there any likelihood of the North Cedar white school being enlarged and if so, would they be willing to accept the Indian children? It would certainly involve a great deal less expense if they attended this school than to drive them to the Nanaimo Indian school.

It has been decided to approve the transportation cost at the rate stated in Indian Agent Moore's letter for the balance of the current academic year provided the distance from their homes to the school does not fall within either of the classes mentioned above.

It should be distinctly understood by all parties
concerned that this is only a temporary arrangement for the balance of the current academic year and should be reviewed before September 1st, 1946.

The teacher should forward a statement to Indian Agent Moore's office at the end of each month telling the number of children that took advantage of transportation, if you find it necessary to make such an arrangement.

Bernard F. Neary

Dear Sir:

At your request we have investigated the heating problem in the basement classroom of the Nanaimo Indian Day School.

We propose that a small booster fan be installed in the warm air duct to increase the air flow to this room.

This fan could be manually controlled by the instructress on duty in order to regulate the heat flow to the classroom.

We could supply and install a booster fan of sufficient capacity for the sum of $37.50. (Thirty-seven Dollars & Fifty cents.)

All estimates are based on the existing costs of equipment, material and labour and are subject to revision.

We trust that this will meet with your approval.

Respectfully submitted,

ATTENTION: MR. R. F. DAVEN.

I should like to refer to your above letter and particularly the last paragraph of same and would advise that I visited this school a couple of weeks ago and found the exits from the basement room and the washrooms a source of annoyance to the teachers and worry to me.

As you know, the toilets are upstairs which means that the pupils from the basement room have to go up there. This means that they leave the lower room -- go half-way up the stairs, out the side door, round to the front of the building and then in to their respective washrooms. The doors are either slammed shut or left open and blow shut and the entire building shakes with the impact. It depends on the direction the wind is blowing whether the door stays open or blows shut. If the former, the basement room is like a barn and, if the latter, the entire class rooms are in a turmoil with noise and papers blowing hither and yon.

I reread your communication and felt that we could not go on like it is at present so thought that, if we could have vacuum door closers installed on two doors, we could get along for the current school year and then, next year, the new doors could be installed and the closers transferred from the old doors to the new as they will be required anyway.

These closers can be installed at a cost of fifty-four dollars ($54.00) and I have asked the Contractor to let me know how soon we could have them put on.

Please advise if I may incur this expenditure as I have never known of a more distracting situation in any school I have ever visited. The teachers and pupils were continually on edge and the wind was blowing through the building so that it was next to impossible to hear what the teacher or pupils were saying.

R. H. MOORE
Superintendent
Cowichan Agency

I am forwarding herewith Supt. Moore's letter of November 25th regarding damage to the windows and the door at the Nanaimo Indian Day School. You will note that Mr. Moore plans on having the windows and the door covered with a heavy screen in an effort to control this periodic damage. The cost of the repairs necessary will be approximately $45.00 and I would recommend that this expenditure be approved.

W. S. Arneil,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.
Mr. W. S. Arneil,
Indian Commissioner for B. C.,
Post Office Box 70,
VANCOUVER, B. C.

During a recent visit to the Nanaimo Indian Day School it was brought to my attention that several panes of glass were broken. The outside side-door panels were broken through being banged with the football and softball from the playground. The blinds needed to be put up and a pin-board erected in the basement class-room.

To get away from broken windows (we replace two dozen each year) and doors in the future I asked that the windows be covered with a heavy screen and the side door also covered by a screen, in an effort to control this damage.

The usual set-up at Nanaimo, with respect to the playground and its proximity to the school building, makes it impossible to prevent breakages unless we take definite precautions and that is exactly what I have done.

Should this door be broken during a holiday or over the weekend the chances are that the school would be entered and supplies stolen.

The total cost of the foregoing will be about forty-five dollars ($45.00) for which I should like authority to expend.

R. H. MOORE
Superintendent
Cowichan Agency

January 20, 1940.

I refer to Mr. Henry's letter of January 15th concerning the tables and chairs in use at the Nanaimo Indian Bay School. The tables shown in the pictures accompanying Inspector Laver's report are 4' wide and 6' long and 30" high. They are covered with Masonite. We have tables of other types in some of our other schools, for example, at the St. George's Residential School; the tables in use in the primary room are 3' long and 2'6" wide. Both of these tables are also in use in many of the Provincial schools. It is generally found that the height of 30" is too high for many of the beginners and at least one table should be provided of 27" in height for this group. In some cases individual tables with a top surface of approximately 18" by 24" are provided, although the Provincial authorities recommend a top surface of 3' by 4' for group tables. It is found that if the room space permits the extra foot in width is desirable. Of the three types mentioned, Inspector Laver prefers the 4' x 6' group table which accommodates six pupils.

The chairs for primary pupils should be 18" and 14" with approximately half of each size provided for each group.

The tables should also have shelves or drawers approximately 4" deep. The tables in use in our schools are equipped with shelves and are found to be quite satisfactory and are cheaper than the graters.
The cost of the 4' by 6' table runs around $50.00. The 2' by 3' table costs about $10.00. The primary chairs 14" high can be secured at varying prices but it has been found that those at about $3.00 are the most satisfactory as they seem to stand up better than the cheaper ones.

Wherever possible the tables should be provided with Masonite tops.

Inspector Davey has requested that he be provided with a flash synchronizer for use in the taking of interior pictures. Mr. Davey has provided himself with his own cameras and is completing a card index of all Indian schools in the province with pictures of each affixed to the cards. This piece of equipment may be purchased for $5.00. It is recommended that the purchase of this be authorized.

W.J. McLean
Commissioner for I.O.

AIR MAIL

November 3rd, 1949.

Mr. W.S. Arneil,
Indian Commissioner,
P.O. Box 70,
Vancouver, B.C.

Re: Voucher 1417 - Cowichan Agency

This Voucher requests payment of $99.00 covering the cost of transporting children from their homes on the Nanaimo River Reserve to the Nanaimo Indian Day School for the month of September. There is also included in the Voucher an item of $4.00 to interview children. Please let us have an explanation for your reason for this particular expenditure.

In view of the contents of official letter of January 21st, 1948, we feel that it is advisable to reconsider the necessity for providing transportation. We would like to know the distance the children reside from the school. It is also noted that in the original request for authority to incur expenditure for transportation (see letter dated January 16th, 1948) it is mentioned that 10 children would take advantage of it. A review of the accounts indicate that for several months past, the number transported is less than 10.

Please let us hear from you.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Education Division
Indian Affairs Branch,
Dept. Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Ont.

Re: Transportation of school children
Nanaimo Reserves 2 and 3
Your file 832-5 (E 1)

With reference to Mr. Phelan's letter of Nov. 3rd, Supt. Moore in his letter of November 15th attached outlines the reason for the $4.00 expenditure included in Cowichan voucher No. 1417, and in view of his explanation the expenditure is considered to be justified.

With regard to the continued provision of transportation for children from the Nanaimo River Reserves, accommodation is not available in the white school for these eight children and as their home conditions apparently are satisfactory it is not felt that they should be admitted to a residential school. It is obviously too far for them to walk to school and consequently payment of $4.00 a day for transportation is recommended.

-W. S. Arneil,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.
Duncan, B.C.

November 15th, 1949.

W.S. Arneil, Esq., Indian Commissioner for B.C., Vancouver, B.C.

Re: Transportation of School Children:
Nanaimo I.R.'s 2 & 3 to Nanaimo I.D.S.

Reference your letter of above date and file, I wish to advise as follows:

(1). The charge of $4.00 by the transportation was to take Mrs Hill to the River Reserves just prior to the opening of school in September so that we might determine the number of pupils immediately available and decide if the bus should be started with the opening of school, or held off for a week or so if the children had not returned to their reserves. This was authorised by me as a precautionary measure to assure ourselves that we would not be providing transportation for two or three pupils only.

(2). As I see the present set-up where the pupils reside a minimum distance of 5 miles from school and a maximum of 6 miles, there is not much that we can do except continue—so long as the present number of children are of school age. If the number get below 6 then we should consider them attending residential school, or, better still, the Cedar Public School—always providing there is room, which there is not at present.

(3). There are eight pupils in attendance from the river reserves, which are the only ones of school age.

(4). There are two trips made daily, one in the morning to pick up the children and take them to school and another in the afternoon to take them home again. The total distance traveled daily is 25 miles, which works out at 20¢ per mile.

R.H. Moore,
Superintendent.

EXTRACT FROM REPORT OF MR. INSPECTOR CAIRNS ON THE NANAIMO INDIAN DAY SCHOOL (April 10, 1924)

I discussed the matter of manual training for the boys with the Rev. Peter R. Kelly and Miss Klippert, the teacher. Both of them are anxious to take up this subject in a scientific way.

They suggested that a partition could be run through the basement and one-half of it used as a manual training room.

I asked Mr. Kelly to interview the manual training teacher for the city of Nanaimo and get from him all the information that possibly could concerning the cost, etc.

When I have this information, I will forward it to the Department of Indian Affairs at Ottawa with recommendations.

R. H. Cairns, Insp.
Ottawa, September 2, 1924.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 6th ultimo, in which you recommend that manual training classes be established at the Squamish Indian Residential School and the Nanaimo Day School. In reply I have to inform you that favourable consideration has been given and I should be pleased if you would inform Agents Perry and Lomas that they should get in touch with proper instructors and each make a definite proposal to the Department. You should explain to them how the work could be undertaken and what equipment will be needed.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Acting Asst. Deputy Secretary.

Sir:

I have to inform you that Rev. P. R. Kelly has again urged the Department to establish manual training activity at the Nanaimo Indian Day School. I have suggested that Mr. Kelly see you and that you present to the Department a proposal and an estimate of the cost of furnishing the equipment and giving the instruction desired.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

Sir:

Having referred to your letter of the 14th April last in regard to Mr. R. Kelly urging the Department to establish manual training at Maniago Indian Bay School, I would inform you that difficulty has been experienced in obtaining an instructor, which I hope will be overcome within the next ten days.

It is expected that the old school building will be utilized as a work shop. I am holding a meeting of the band on the 7th instant when I expect the building will be arranged for.

I might say in conclusion that I am surprised at Mr. Kelly's activities regarding the manual training school while at Ottawa, and would say, that had it not been for unfulfilled promises of assistance on his part, the matter would of already been arranged.

Your obedient servant,
