The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa
Sir,

Having further reference to yours of the 14th April in connection with proposed Manual Training in the Nanaimo Indian Day School, I beg to report as follows:

The question of a building for manual training has been gone into and the Indians of the Band have consented to allow the old schoolhouse for Training. The old building is suitably situated and affords good light. It will be necessary to have the building re-shingled at a cost of approximately $100.00.

As regards work benches, these can be procured from the Kuper Island Industrial School, and are the property of the Department.

The approximate cost of carpenters tools, etc., as per list forwarded me by Mr. R. H. Cairns, Inspector of Indian Schools, for 10 pupils, would be approximately $275.00. In addition to this, material for work would be required, but would not involve a great expense.

I have taken the matter up as regards an instructor and have correspondence from Mr. J. G. Somerville, Manual Training Instructor of Nanaimo City and other schools, who from personal knowledge, I know to be an experienced instructor, who quotes his price at $32.50 per month; this would be two sessions per week, and from 8 to 10 sessions per month.

The question of holding this training on Saturdays, has been suggested by Rev. P. R. Kelly, Missionary at Nanaimo. Such an action would be unwise indeed. Most of the pupils have a great distance to come to school, and it is thought that having studied all week, it would be detrimental to their health to deprive them of the weekend holiday.

Your obedient servant,

(Alfred H. Lomas)
Indian Agent.

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
June 30, 1925.

Memorandum:

Dr. Scott,

For some time I have corresponded with Mr. Inspector Caima, Mr. Indian Agent Lomas and the Rev. Mr. Kelly, with reference to commencing a manual training class at the Nanaimo Indian Day School. Work benches can be secured without cost, except freight. The proposed programme will mean $32.50 per month for the instructor plus a small sum for working materials. The only outfit that will have to be purchased now is tools, which can be secured for approximately $250. I am keen on trying this activity at one good day school in B.C. and should be pleased to have your approval for the expenditure.

Russell J. Ferrier
Supt. of Indian Education.
Ottawa, June 30, 1926.

Sir:

I have your 798-4-2 of the 19th inst., with reference to manual training activity at the Nanaimo Indian Day School. I note that the old school house can be used for this special activity and that it will be necessary to re-shingle it at a cost of approximately $100. You are authorized to have this repair effected without delay. Secure competitive prices before purchasing the shingles and give the labour to Indians. Labour returns in duplicate should be kept, showing the time of the men employed and their receipts for wages.

Please make the necessary arrangements to secure a suitable number of work benches from the Upper Island Indian Residential School. The receipted accounts for freight should be forwarded to the Department and reimbursement will be made.

I note that Mr. Inspector Cairns has submitted a list of tools suitable for 10 pupils. The Department considers that the instructor should cooperate in the selection of what is needed and I have to ask you to keep the expenditure in this connection under $250. When you are submitting the account, in duplicate, in favour of the firm given the business, support it with a memo showing the firms asked to quote and the prices quoted.

You may engage the services of Mr. J. G. Somerville, the manual training instructor for Nanaimo City Schools. Payment at the rate of $4.00 per three hours' session will be allowed. It is understood that there will be two sections per week. Remuneration fees in this manner will be more satisfactory to the Department than so much per month. Please explain to Mr. Somerville.

The Department agrees that two half days during the school week should be devoted to this purpose and that it will not be necessary to have the special classes on Saturday. Please explain to the teacher that the Department expects her to teach the girls while the boys are at manual training and to give them special lessons in sewing, darning and related activities.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. Macdonald,
Acting Asst. Deputy Secretary.

Indian Agent,
Duncan, B. C.
